description:
Wow.  What a Great find and just a few blocks from UCSF.  Great to eat alone or in small groups too. 
The poke bowl is huge and fresh with lots of protein. The lunch specials are all 8-12 and so good very large portions. And the bento box is huge portions too.  
Bus stop right across, limited parking
author: David C.

description: This place has the worst service! Went there with my friends who all ordered food and I was just there with them for company as I had just eaten. And the waitress/owner asked me to leave as I was taking up space . Very poor customer service!
author: Silpa J.

description: Small location that serves decent food. We got the chicken bento and salmon sashimi. Slow service though. This was our second attempt to eat here, we left the first time because they took too long to get to seat us.
author: Sunil R.

description: Got the bento box lunch special. Decent size portions and price point... however the quality was mediocre. A solid 3 star place.
author: Sandy Y.

description:
It's so hard for me leave a bad review because I've been coming here for so long. I'll leave this in hopes of helping them to improve. 

I typically cal in my order 20 mins prior to picking it up. I  always order the teriyaki chicken bowl extra crispy. I got there and stopped at the counter. The lad said hi then looked behind me and seated them. That kind of through me for a loop cause she didn't say one minute or how can I help. But I'm going to assume she remembered and knew me and knew I ordered to go. 

After seating them she asked how can I help you? (Confused- safe to say she must have not known). I told her I ordered and gave her my name. I could see my order sitting on the counter behind her. I gave my card to pay and noticed the score card tucked behind the counter (82 ). That made me kinda sad and a little grossed out. She gave my card back and ran out the front door to pop her trunk and let a delivery guy put some things in and stood to talk. I stepped outside and said "hey my food is right there and I paid, can I just grab it or?" She runs back in straight to the pick up food counter. The cook says something to her, she run to the seated area took a tray of sushi off someone's table and gave it back to the cook through the window. I lean over again and say "umm can I get my food please". She says ohh ohh and run back to the counter and gives me a fork and napkin. I ask for an extra teriyaki sauce (as always). So at this point I have my tray of food, napkin, fork, recipes and extra sauce container and she is kinda rushing like thank you!!! Bye. I say can I please have a bag. She says 10cents. I said you didn't ask me before you ran my card, I don't have cash. She pauses and looks at me, I look at her she looks at me. I say "forget it I can just carry everything". And as I'm walking out the door she say here's a bag- no thanks!!

And it's again at this point that I realize why they have that 82. Smh. And also realize that as she ran to the trunk and used her hands to open it etc she came right back in and touched that tray of sushi. And tried to put my extra sauce inside my food. I stopped her knowing that her hands touching the sauce weren't clean and stopped her from sitting inside on top of my actual food

Do better guys. Bittersweet

P.S. my food was NOT extra crispy
author: Latrice W.

description: It's real close to home so I thought this would be great.  Food here is fine, nothing outstanding but that's fine with me because sometimes you just want the old fashion standard Japanese restaurant fare.  Since I live so close, I always want to get take-out, go home, take off my footwear, put on some old (ugly) home clothes, put the hair up--I don't care how I look, I just want to be home comfy.  However, You See Sushi had a policy for a while, might still be on but haven't checked since it completely discouraged me, that they would do take out but you had to have your order in early enough the day before.  I never know what I'm going to want to eat the next day--and for just maybe 6-8 pieces of regular sushi, nothing fancy???  Sorry, I'll go to one of the other sushi places in the neighborhood.
author: Kai T.

description:
Lovely cute little sushi place! Waitress was really friendly!

Great cost:quality ratio, very cheap sushi! (But very nice too!)

Nice neighbourhood spot, will be visiting again!
author: Mark L.

description: Ok place to get some sushi or a bento box. But do note that they don't serve beef. I've tried their chicken teriyaki (very basic), tempura, and different sushi. Overall, not bad, but I'd prefer the latter two items better. Affordable place to get full on.
author: Ali F.

description: Delicious and intimate sushi spot! Street parking can be hard to find at times but worth it. Affordable pricing.
author: Jessica P.

description: Was in the mood for amazing sushi and I found a new love! You See Sushi is so fresh and yummy!!!! Iku is sweet and the food ... Omg!
author: Marissa C.

description:
"You see me, babe? You see me, babe? Asian girls everywhere, UCLA." -Childish Gambino, You See Me

I'm guessing the name comes from the proximity to UCSF, which is definitely where a large proportion of You See Sushi's customer base comes from. You See is nothing fancy, but it is solid simple Japanese food. The fish is relatively fresh and the rice is soft and seasoned. I highly recommend their reasonable lunch specials--you can get a filling sushi meal for less than $10, which includes miso soup and a few bites of salad. Not bad! Hot green tea is also complimentary. Besides sushi, they also have quite filling bentos (think teriyaki chicken). 

All of my interactions with the service have been pleasant and we haven't had a problem with splitting a bill three ways. You See is good for takeout or eating in, especially with a friend or two (not enough room for a huge party though). Go here for a quick, cheap lunch or dinner, then head right back to UCSF to study or work or whatever.
author: Jade V.

description:
You See Sushi is close to UCSF and on the Judah metro line.  Parking is a little better than the 9th avenue area ( three blocks away) as it is still residential and at the cusp of the commercial / food district.  Found parking pretty quickly.

The restaurant is not a fancy date place but more of a place to just fill your stomach.  Probably gets a lot of lunch business from UCSF.  Inexpensive, fresh fish, different interpretations on certain items (Pass on the Poke Bowl and the Fried Shitaki Mushroon Tempura Roll), Chicken Teriaki Bento is decent, Sushi and Rolls are cheap as portion sizes are smaller than other places but enough to fill you up.

Complimentary Tea and Miso Soup.  Fast service.  Good diner type place when you need to fill the stomach.
author: Scott L.

description:
It's definitely a good and cheap place to get your sushi fill in.

The service here was very excellent. Shout out to the waitress that waited our food. I ordered the combo number 1 and 2 maki, and she told me that I couldn't finish it and should stop on that second maki. I loled because I'm a big eater. But that recommendation and friendliness was just definitely something to brighten up the dinner.

The sushi was decent for the price of $13. I had a good 5 pieces of Nigiri. The rice and the craftsmanship is nice. The miso soup had carrots in them, but it was savory and not as watered down as some other sushi diner. The maki is the part that I had confused. I ordered the sake negi maki, but I didn't taste any salmon at all. That was interesting.

Overall, it was a nice diner with decent food and excellent customer service. If I had $20 in my pocket, and I want a nice sushi fill. I will definitely come back.
author: Jian G.

description: The best sushi in inner sunset and maybe the city. This is amazing, and it's affordable. They are all so friendly and the food is just delicious. This is hands down, my favorite sushi place in town.
author: Carmen C.

description: This is one of my favorite sushi places in the city because it is close by UCSF and it is very convenient for students and nurse having a quick lunch in a short break. They have really good price on anything and the sushi always very fresh and tasty . Waitress are very nice and I am always have nice experience here and for sure I will keep coming back .
author: Ying Ying Y.

description: Nice selection of veggie rolls.  The location is very conveniently walking distance from the UCSF library.  The prices are very affordable.  The waitress was extremely attentive and friendly.  We came right at the start of dinner time, and there wasn't any wait.
author: SF O.

description:
Perfect location if you work/ study/ visit at UCSF, or the inner Sunset area. Although the interior is small, around 10 tables total, it is quite comfortable. I did not feel crammed or rushed while eating there, staff are also very friendly. It was a very relaxing lunch dining experience. 

The lunch special menu is affordable and filling, usually come with your sushi of choice plus a few other pieces of sushi, a bowl of rice with teriyaki sauce and miso soup. I did not know that the sushi has hidden wasabi in them, so be aware if you cannot tolerate wasabi at all (like me).  I especially like the teriyaki sauce, it is just the right level of sweetness and saltiness. Rice in the sushi is soft and fish are fresh. Although the meal is simple, every component is well made. 

There are just little things that show the quality of You See Sushi is above average, like the veggies in the miso soup, and sesame on teriyaki sauce. The fact that they spend time with the plating and presentation of the sushi plate during lunch time rush hours is very impressive alone. Will come back for sure!
author: Karen C.

description:
Enter You See Sushi-

As I was seated Cher was singing "Do you believe in life after love?" 

A: well not sure, I'm pretty optimistic in life but also kinda jaded at the moment and found out I'm going through Saturn's return rn (S/O Gwen Stefani and crew). But what I DO believe is that You See Sushi over-delivered on its promise. Summary below:

What I saw: sushi -BUT ALSO- edamame, miso soup, happy people eating and on dates and the like, a friendly and caring staff, my swell friend Ken eating across from me, and a cheap bill. I thought I would only see sushi so this alone makes me give some extra stars, way to over-deliver y'all! 

What the staff saw: me and my friend Ken leaving with full bellies and smiles on our faces. F'in NAILED IT!

Well Cher, I guess SEEING -is- believing. And You See Sushi, I am now a believer. Thanks for the memories y'all. In the seafood industry we would call a place like this quite the...catch. Thank you and good night folks.

Much love.
author: Matt B.

description:
I've now been 3 times, and know I'll be back for more!

The fish is good, the portions are big, and the value is excellent! I've had poke, sushi, and bento boxes, and have not been disappointed with anything yet. 

If I worked at UC Med I'd be a regular at lunch ( same huge portions, but even cheaper!)

Parking in this neighborhood is challenging.
author: El B.

description: Lunch specials FTW! This place saves me from eating repetitive cafeteria food at work & is friendly to my wallet. I always seem to catch this place when it closes but luckily was able to grab a bite here during lunch with my coworker. We both ordered lunch bentos accompanied with miso soup and one philly roll. I liked the facts that my teriyaki chicken + tempura were crunchy, teriyaki sauce was slightly sweet, salad dressing was tasty, & the tea was piping hot! The Philadelphia Roll tasted fresh while the rice to fish ratio was good. Overall portion size & food quality exceeded my expectations for it's price. I can't wait to go to lunch here again!
author: Jenn C.

description:
Looking for the most bang for your buck? You See Sushi will suffice. Their fish quality is reflected in the cheap, under $10 price range. I haven't gotten sick from eating yet here, but I have generally felt disappointed after my meals here, both dine-in and take-out.

The fish for the nigiri is mushy, flavorless, and lackluster. Avoid the raw items (nigiri, sashimi) and stick to the cooked items and Westernized sushi instead. If you want quality and freshness, look elsewhere; Kazu is a good option in the vicinity.
author: Priscilla W.

description: I feel compelled to write a review because the owner was SO nice and sweet. She was so attentive  to me and even ran my water bottle out to me when I left it on the table! The sushi was good and I liked that the miso soup had bits of veggies in it. I will definitely be back.
author: Amanda S.

description:
You See Sushi is great quality at a very low cost. I'm incredibly impressed by what a great time I had eating low cost sushi. 

I ordered the Sushi Dinner combo #3, with a tempura roll, a eel and avocado roll, and 4 pieces of Nigiri chosen by the chef (tuna, white tuna, salmon, shrimp). All of this came out to only 12.49, so I was skeptical of the quality. But I was incredibly impressed! The tempura roll was great (shrimp remained crunchy inside the roll), and the avocado and eel roll was exceptional. The eel and avocado didn't have the fishy taste that many poor sushi places get wrong. Definitely not a top tier restaurant quality, but still very good and extremely satisfying. 

The four pieces of Nigiri are quite large, and comes with wasabi applied between the fish and rice (which is how it's supposed to be presented). My friend complained there was too much, but I thought the wasabi was great. The quality of the fish clearly isn't the best in the world, but it still tastes incredible, and it's exactly what I was going for. Would recommend!

The restaurant is nice and cozy, very quaint and homely. However, service took very long, especially since both of us had such simple orders.

Would recommend for anyone, 4.3/5.
author: Ben Z.

description:
It was a Saturday night, around 9:12PM and the place I originally wanted to go to was closing in minutes so I yelped the nearest place that was still open and Yoo See Sushi popped up and thank goodness they were open until 10PM because I was craving for sake bombs and sushi. 

The parking is typical San Francisco parking. Gotta scout out for that 2 hour parking sign and maybe try to find parking in front of the restaurant, if you're lucky. 

The inside is small, there's 2 different dining areas, my boyfriend and I were seated in the bigger dining area. There weren't that many people out during this time and we were the only ones there, a guy eventually came in for a little bit but that was about it. 

Our waitress was alright, she checked in on us once and wasn't impressionable. A little on the bland boring side, probably because it was slow and there wasn't much to do. 

F O O D :
I ordered #2 dinner combo:
Teriyaki chicken w/ tempura (veggie or shrimp), side salad and 3pcs California roll. $12~ 
Portion size is definitely worth the price. I wasn't a fan of the side salad, but I didn't care because the real prize of this bento was the chicken teriyaki. It was crunchy, sweet and charred enough for even my liking(and I love me some super charred food). Other reviewers mentioned that their chicken teriyaki is the BOMB.COM and I definitely put my hands up to agreement on that *insert hands up emoji*. The other sides of the bento: veggie tempura and California rolls fell flat short after I took my first bite of that sweet delicious bento entree. 

Would I come back? Let's just say that I've been cooking chicken teriyaki at home (not as good as You See Sushi of course) and sadly eating my failure in attempt to hold myself until I can come back here again to get more of it.
author: Grace Anne D.

description: I go here with my cowrkrs about 1-2 times a month. really nice hole in the wall. service is good. I always get the lunch bento #2 with a coke runs $13+ but its worth it. and if I'm not mistaken they can deliver through doordash
author: Ava J.

description:
After coming here, it makes me not want to eat sushi for a very long time. This is the worst sushi I've ever had in my entire life. 

Don't make the same mistake I made and order the sashimi dinner. The sashimi dinner comes with 4 types of fish, and one of them tasted so bad we couldn't finish it. If you happen to be here, order the super simple rolls, but try to not come here. The avocado and eel roll was not as bad as everything else, but the main part of our dinner, the sashimi, made me want to throw up as I tried to finish it (I didn't finish it).
author: Guorui W.

description:
This is your hidden neighborhood gem. It is cheap and decent quality. It really is made for all the UCSF students nearby. I don't see why you would come otherwise or you just live in the area. It is small and cramped, but really the value here is unsurpassed. They are usually understaffed initially, but really this is your neighborhood joint that you should support! That's what Yelp was founded on right?

I mean this is really a 3.5 star, but a place like this can't afford to have a sub 4 star rating. Most people will overlook it. If you just need a quick cheap bite this is it. Look at the pictures! It's not bad. Ok, the parking might stink too, but you're a student that lives nearby or a resident so perfect, you don't need the parking. 

Come for your Americanized Japanese bento boxes made well and cheap. The rice is always fresh here and the lunch specials are the real gem of it all.

In all my years of coming here (I swear I was here some 15 years ago) the little details are evident like the cabbage in your miso soup or the extra sesame seeds in your teriyaki sauce even when they are understaffed and the little restaurant gets over filled. I'm proud to be a fan and a life long fan as a native San Franciscan.

Cheers!
author: Joseph L.

description: Cheap lunch specials! Came back with some coworkers and we each ordered a bento box with chicken teriyaki and California rolls for under $7 each. Good value, although the lunch time rush was a little busy.
author: Corinna T.

description: I really like this place and I love the server there. The sushi is good and well priced and it has a nice atmosphere. I go there a lot with my friends, its easy and fun.
author: Maya P.

description:
I recently came and enjoyed the ambience and atmosphere. The staff is relatively friendly. This is by far one of my siblings favorite sushi bars. The dinner specials are good and the tea provided is good as well.

The Unagi rolls are good although I have had better rolls at other locations. The portion size for the chicken teriyaki meal is also quite good. I recommend as a sushi bar to try. Not sure however that it meets my list of favorite sushi bars however. Maybe with additional visits I may come around. Staying optimistic ...
author: Jeffrey N.

description: Possible pun because of the close proximity to UCSF?? Nothing special about this place. The food was fine and the service was fine, but nothing was outstanding. Shared sushi and tempura. Everything is commensurately priced. You're not overpaying for anything mediocre and you're not underpaying for anything great
author: Jamie F.

description:
With a curious name that is noticeably not Japanese-sounding, a modestly simple storefront, and too-good-to-be-true proximity to campus, you would expect Panda-Express-grade sushi.  However when I Saw Sushi, it did not disappoint P:

[MENU]

Their menu, especially lunch specials, are very affordable (at med school, this place is referred to as student-friendly, as opposed to resident-friendly and attending-friendly).  The portions are also just enough to leave you satisfied without sinking into food coma.  The prices are a bit higher than Kiki's, but quality is much better--a place where you can eat sushi and actually taste the sashimi, rather than having to order rolls slathered in sauce in order to cover up stale fish.  Variety is also more limited, as you won't be able to satisfy your oyako-don cravings, but they do have a specials menu board posted on the wall.

[LUNCH SPECIAL]

My favorite is the lunch special #2 with a spicy tuna roll and 4 pieces of nigiri.   It comes with miso soup and a bowl of rice in teriyaki sauce--simple but good.  The tea is served in these vintage mugs with cartoons of sushi, which is actually quite helpful as a quick reference guide in case you forget the Japanese names of fish.

[SERVICE]

Although we were off to a bit of a rocky start and had to switch tables after sitting down, overall service is very friendly; you are well taken care of by mama-sans.  They were prompt and attentive, continuously checking up on us to make sure they could take our orders once we were ready.  It was also very nice of them to warn me that some people don't like the mackerel that came with my special, and that I had the option to substitute if I wanted.

[AMBIANCE]

The ambiance on the inside is quite nice, surpassing what you'd expect from the unpretentious green awning on the outside: clean, simple, comfortable.  It's not a big place, but does not feel cramped.  There's an aesthetic window in the middle of the restaurant, which I at first thought was a mirror illusion but it turned out to be forreals.

[AFTERTHOUGHT]

Note to Cal Bears: I swear, You See Sushi must be a psychological subliminal message, kindling fond memories of CU Sushi. Although the styles are quite different, the consistent quality and convenience make both a go-to student staple. In fact, I am continually mixing up the names (UC Sushi, See You Sushi... -_-) which always makes me look silly to everyone other than Golden Bears who are in the same predicament.
author: Edna C.

description: Pretty decently priced sushi and also really good! The tempura wasn't the best I've ever had, but overall for the price it was great. And very good miso soup. We were there I guess at a not so busy time but the lady working there was fantastic paying very close attention to when we needed anything.  Also very close to UCSF campus which is convenient for us students.
author: Paige L.

description:
This place is a cute mom and pop restaurant hidden in the heart of Inner Sunset. Literally though, the owners are a married duo who has owned this place since 1991. The food is great and so are the prices like everyone says. The bento boxes are especially great because if you sit by the table closest to the kitchen, the hot tempura only has to travel 3 feet to get you so its fresh out of the oil! A few of my favorite rolls are the forty-niner roll (scallops and avocado, salmon on top with lemon), the philly roll (salmon, avocado, and cream cheese), and the samurai roll (seaweed salad with grilled salmon on the outside). Yum, I'm drooling just thinking about it~ 

I've been here for years and I love how cozy and welcoming they are. Its definitely worth braving the cold for.
author: Shawna T.

description: Great price for a lunch bento box, and good sushi! Satisfied my cravings ! Wasn't the best sushi I've had but if you're looking for a quick good price I'd go ! I'll prob give another try if I'm in the area. The sashimi was fresh
author: Linda G.

description:
Cheap and convenient are the main draws of You See Sushi. It's literally across the street from our apartment so it's easy to stop by after work.

Their lunch and dinner specials are good deals (especially lunch). The sushi is okay, but not amazing.

If you are looking for spectacular sushi, you'll have to look elsewhere, but for simple rolls it's a good, local option.
author: Annaliese D.

description: Came upon this little place by chance, and glad I found it!  It's near UCSF Parnassus and was packed with people.  The menu was extensive and the fish was super fresh - melt in your mouth sushi!  The prices were great as was the service.  It is a family run operation, and they do it well.  Happy to support a business like this.  If you're looking for great sushi, tempura, teriyaki, it's well worth the trip!
author: Evan K.

description: I've been waiting a whole hour  for my food and people that stand down after me are eating. They have barely given me water. Wish I could rate the food, but I am very hangry right now :(
author: diana b.

description:
Not cheap enough for the subpar sushi and fish quality across the board. Of all the salmon sashimi I've tried, the salmon here has by far the saddest coloring and taste. Based on the quality, I had serious doubts that the salmon they cut here is actually sashimi grade, though thank goodness it didn't give me food poisoning afterwards.

Much better off to stock up on cheap sushi fix from Nijiya Market instead, even more affordable and also quality lvl+ x100 in comparison to You See Sushi. Or, if you're looking for a sit-down place, Tenroku is similarly priced with Nijiya Market's fish quality.
author: Tian Q.

description:
Come between 11:30 AM - 2:30 PM to order the sushi lunch special #2.

For $6.95, you get 6 pieces of SPICY TUNA & AVOCADO ROLL, along with 4 nigiri of yellowtail, mackerel, albacore, and salmon (http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/-839ZQTU1eOfV2UQ7HIdpw/l.jpg). Meals come with complimentary green tea, and the lunch special also gets you a bowl of rice and miso soup.

Health conscious and affordable, the way it should always be :)
author: Adele F.

description: SO GOOD. great service, yummy sushi, nice presentation, lots of seating, and affordable prices. my favorite sushi spot in sf!
author: Jenny L.

description:
Sushi on a college budget? I'm a fan. 

Came here with a group of friends in the later evening on a Friday night. Parking was found on side streets. The place had a couple tables there. 

We ordered a mix of bento boxes, udon, sashimi and sushi. The bento boxes came with a different kind of miso soup - a borsch type of miso soup. You could tell this place was not run by Japanese (but I didn't mind). 

The bento boxes were filling and sashimi was sufficient. It wasn't the best quality but I didn't get sick. If I'm in the area and need some easy Japanese, this is my go-to.

Would I drive specifically out here? No :(
author: Stephanie W.

description:
This is the only place I go for sushi, and I have been coming here for years.
Their food is absolutely delicious .  We love this place!

 the owners are hard-working and personable, the food is delicious and reasonably priced. For myself, I've ordered the chicken teriyaki with extra sauce every time we come here. The gyoza   is also very good. Spicy California rolls are a must as are all the other sushi rolls. End your meal with mochi and you'll walk out a happy person :-)
author: Scott H.

description:
Affordable sushi
Decent staff
Centrally located
Food is not premium but it's still tasty
What more do you want?
author: Bimbo B.

description: Walking distance from UCSF. Real food unlike the hospital cafeteria. Great food. Great presentation. Friendly people. Hawaii roll and California roll were my choice.
author: Z M.

description:
Don't expect top quality sushi or sashimi here because this local hole in the wall is only good for lunch. Since UCSF Parnasus is right up the street, this place is a mad house during lunch time and sometimes at dinner too. I see more people taking food to go than dining in. Its local, palatable and they gave me more rice than usual. 

Perhaps the only drawback when ordering a nigiri or a roll is the amount of rice they really give you. I ordered an uni nigiri because I wasn't very hungry, so like a snack. There was more rice than uni in there. FOR REAL?! Lame. 

Ah well...I was satiated.
author: Jason C. J.

description: Absolutely love their unagi don (eel over rice). It's the best eel I have ever tried, and I've tried unagi at every japanese restaurant I've ever been to. Only comment is that it's a very small and intimate place, not a lot of seating.
author: Mary G.

description: This is a small sushi joint conveniently located near UCSF. I came here around 5:15pm on a Tuesday and we were seated immediately. The service was quick and efficient - our food took very little time to prepare. I ordered a salmon avocado roll (~$4) and a yellowtail scallion roll (~$4). The both were okay but certainly nowhere near the quality of sushi I typically eat. The fish wasn't very fresh nor generous. The avocado was browning slightly. My friend got the teriyaki chicken bento box (~$8.50)- which was much more tasty than mine. I would recommend going for that rather than the sushi if you're going to dine here.
author: Nicole J.

description:
The Good - Great prices, great location, fresh ! Small family business serving the neighborhood and UCSF staff, patients and their families. I've been eating here 2x week for the last two years and the quality of food has been consistently excellent. It's nice to have a lunch place where the owners know you, that's what makes a neighborhood.

The Bad -  "What bad ? ? ? "Small family owned business  with limited tables - NOT A CHAIN - lunch time can get busy and if you arrive between 12:15 and 1 p.m. expect a wait. 

The Ugly - No ugly, except all the self-entitled suburban refugees on this site who think they're writing for 'Gourmet' magazine and want immediate gratification ... for those folks "Panda Express is just up the street, you won't know the difference". 

 = )

Btw - great for dinner, quiet, no wait, most of their business seems to be take-out for UCSF staff leaving the tables free for those of us who want to dine in.
author: Joe 9.

description:
No fresh fish plus the wait is not worth it! I had to get up and leave for waiting so long. I think this is convenient for some people who work and go to school at UCSF and this is the reason why people still go here...I love sushi but not over here!!

Even the icecream tasted like it has been near the sink where you wash dishes at. yuck
author: Alayna C.

description:
I stopped by You See Sushi for my friend's birthday dinner. It's a pretty small place so I thought it was strange that she decided to have her dinner there but after seeing the prices on the menu, I understood.

The scary thing about super cheap prices is worrying about quality. To see cheap prices on sushi is quite enticing regardless. I was still really full from lunch so I only ordered a small order of unagi (eel) sashimi in 3 pieces and a side order of miso soup. Everyone else ordered TONS of sushi.

Service was nice but it took them FOREVER to bring our order out. Initially, I figured it was because we had a big group and we ordered a lot but they forgot someone's 2nd order later on. 

My eel was pretty good. The miso soup however, is really strange. It had carrots and cabbage which is something I'm not used to at all. Not bad, just different. I didn't actually like the taste though. I'm not sure what everyone else's thoughts were, but I didn't like it. Cheap though! 

My friend let me sample some of their orders: tuna sashimi, salmon sashimi, uni sashimi, lady in red roll, philly roll, rock n' roll, and some other stuff that I forgot the name of. 

The sashimi is good. No different from other places. The rolls were really good though and I'm impressed because they're cheap. My personal favorite is the lady in red. 

Good place.
author: Sofia R.

description:
Great for a college student on a budget.  Came in with my friend who's been there before.  They had "meals" for their dinner specials.  I got the Special Dinner meal #2. It consisted of: Spicy Tuna & Avocado Roll (6 pieces), Cucumber Roll (6 pieces), Nigiri (one piece each): Tuna, Eel, Albacore, Salmon, Yellowtail & Inari, miso soup for $9.95.  I added a Tako-Maki (Octopus) (6 pieces) for around $2.15? I am not exact on the prices but overall it was cheap.  The rolls are a bit small hence the cheap prices, but I was pretty satisfied with my meal.

Their miso soup was different instead of tofu and seaweed it had cabbage and carrots.  Also, instead of the traditional edamame when you are seated we got a mugful of carrot sticks.  

Overall, I was satisfied with the food for what I paid.  Not a bad way to get a sushi fix if you are on a budget.  If I am in the neighborhood I will be roaming around again.  There's a lot more I would like to check out on their menu.

Note: It is a bit small and cramp inside, but for a cheap sushi place what more can you ask for? Our waitress was also VERY friendly and hospitable.
author: Belinda T.

description: Yummy, inexpensive food. The wait was torture because we were starvin marvins and when the food finally came out we demolished our rolls faster than our stomachs could keep up. Small dining room, which made it a bit uncomfortable to stand in line waiting with our butts in the faces of people eating their dinner. Overall, good experience. Would try it again, but not before checking out other sushi places in sf
author: Molly D.

description: Good bento lunch. Good price. Busy for lunch.  Best of all 2 blocks from today's work. Was able to eat in 30 min.
author: tomohisa w.

description: Best lunch box special in SF I've found so far! 6.95$ - 9.95$ gets you a full stomach and variety of foods! I always have to come here when I'm around!
author: Vance O.

description:
If you're looking for quality sushi or sashimi, You See Sushi would probably NOT be the place to go to. But if you're looking for a quick fix of basic and mediocre Japanese food, this would be the place.

Located right down the block from UCSF (Parnassus campus), this small restaurant is usually packed between the hours of 12 to 2 pm, so be prepared to go earlier or to wait. For seven dollar Bento boxes, one gets miso soup, salad (or rice), and then anything ranging from CA rolls to spicy tuna, tempura to meat teriyakis. Not exactly the most mouthwatering thing you'll have ever eaten, but for 7 dollars, probably more than sufficient. After all, you do get what you paid for.

I did try to deviate from the norm and ordered uni nigiri (sea urchin)- $3.95 for 2 pieces- and I would not recommend it to anyone. Normally fresh uni is sweet/ little fishy (more of an acquired taste), but here it was extremely fishy, slimy, and wet...  Should've gone with what everyone else was ordering. Lesson learned.
author: Ada C.

description: Really, really good sushi for the price. Fresh fish and a nice selection of specialty rolls.
author: X-topher B.

description:
I got to go, so can't comment on the service. 

The food was pretty good, I thought they could have made the rolls bigger. Overall taste was good. Inexpensive some what for sushi but then again portions aren't so big.
author: Anna B.

description:
If you go, just try one of their bento-style combos, just don't get your hopes up too much. It's a mediocre meal at a mediocre price. I would go back again because their combos are quickly served, reasonably priced, taste as you'd expect, and the service was good, but it's not something I'd write home about.

I tried their sashimi combo, a mistake I will never make again. It was expensive and not tasty at all, at the end I was just forcing it down because I needed to eat, but under different circumstances I might have juat thrown it away. Oh, and I should add that I'm not at all a sushi snob, I've eaten tons of cheap sushi before and pretty much enjoyed it all, so for me to not like it is not good.

Sashimi combo: 0/5
Unagi bowl: 3/5
Bento-style combos: 3/5
author: Taemin J.

description:
I love this place.  I've been coming here since they were "We Be Sushi".  Same owners, different name.  Honestly, I'd have to say I love "You See" better since their so clever being right down the street from UCSF.

Really simple, fresh sushi.  Nothing fancy.  Their prices have stayed relatively the same for the past 10 years I've been coming here.  The teriyaki chicken bento box is one of my favorites anywhere.  It's crispy and with just the right amount of sauce.  Otherwise, ordering sushi ala carte is awesome.
author: Alice L.

description: Been going here for many, many, years...does anyone remember when it was callede "We Be Sushi."..wow, now that's way way back.  It's a great place to get some quick Japanese Food.  Sushi is okay and lunch menu is good.  Not high end sushi, but it works.
author: Marjorie G.

description:
One of my favorite sushi spots in the city. It's Japanese owned (bonus) and the sushi isn't expensive and overrated like other spots in this hood. I feel like it took years to find a decent spot as most places over change for over filled mayonnaise rolls. 

I highly recommend the salmon tempura roll and asparagus tempura roll. Totally yummy. 


The only negative is the seating isn't very comfortable (tables are really close) and the tables are always sticky. Families seem to enjoy this place, which is great but can sometimes mean bratty kids screaming next to you and I mean right next to you. The sushi makes up for that though.
author: Giordano G.

description: Exactly what you'd expect for quick, cheap sushi. Nice place to grab a bento box lunch next to UCSF. For higher quality go to Ebisu.
author: Melanie M.

description:
This was my 3rd time going here.  It's about 3 blocks from my apartment--and I eat out a couple times a week, if that tells you anything.

I really like sushi.  Sashimi, udon, tempera, hand rolls, simple rolls, fried rolls..you get the idea.

The food here is pretty simple.  It's not that good.  It's not bad.  They give you free tea, and the ambiance is fine.  It can feel a little bit tight sometimes, like the tables are pushed really close together.

I ordered a lunch special #2.  It came with 6 pieces of spicy tuna and sashimi, miso soup, and rice.  I enjoyed it.

I guess my problem is that it's not CHEAP enough for me to go just because it's cheap, and it's not GOOD enough to really warrant going that often.  If I want good sushi with a nice ambiance, I'll go elsewhere.  But overall, I can't really complain.
author: Aly A.

description: Fantastic sushi prices.  Tastes pretty good.
author: Javier G.

description: Five stars bc they have the great service and my team loves coming here for their lunch boxes! My favorite is the poke salad
author: Sophie N.

description:
This review is for their chicken teriyaki lunch special.

Rice was mushy, more like a porridge.
Chicken was burnt.
The salad greens were browned and wilted.
The CA rolls were as expected.

This is the second and last time I'm going here for lunch (work down the street at UCSF). Maybe they're two isolated incidents, but I don't care to spend more money and figure that out.
author: Dan K.

description:
Not the best sushi but it's a good value at super cheap prices by Inner Sunset standards - perfect for a starving student's budget or if you're just not up to spending $$$ for a decent meal.

They have lunch bento boxes and pretty fresh sushi/sashimi plates starting at $6.95 (!!), and handrolls for $3.50, which all used to be even cheaper until they had to remodel their restaurant for wheelchair accessibility compliance. If there's one type of fish you don't eat, they are more than accommodating in replacing it with another one on the list for no extra charge.

Service is friendly and food comes out fast. They also accept multiple credit cards for bigger groups which is rare for such a tiny place.
author: Liana L.

description: Amazing spicy tuna, great service, nice quiet atmosphere
author: Daniel C.

description:
You See Sushi is a cheaper Japanese restaurant near UCSF's Parnassus campus. The joint is pretty popular with the university crowd, especially during lunch, with its more affordable lunch menus.

- The lunch menu contains a variety of items with a wide spectrum of prices. On the cheaper end are a vegetarian bento box ($7) or a chicken teriyaki/California roll bento box ($7). More expensive options are unagi (BBQ eel) over rice ($14) or sashimi lunch special ($16). The prices seem a little funny to me - the cheap items are really great deals, whereas the more expensive lunch specials seem a little overpriced to me, at least by hole-in-the-wall cheap Japanese standards.
- The service I received here was inexplicably rude. It may have been an English language issue, but I found the workers here unfriendly.
- I was not impressed with the food. The miso soup tasted like the instant kind. The tempura was oily and soggy (instead of very light and crispy). The chicken teriyaki was dry. The California rolls were fine, though somewhat misshapen.

The star rating for You See Sushi is difficult to gauge. On the one hand, it's pretty affordable, which is something you can't say about most Japanese restaurants in the city. On the other hand, the food isn't too great, though perhaps one shouldn't expect it to be great for the price. In the end, I feel like the experience here could have been better, even given the affordable price.
author: Sidney L.

description: So I've eaten here 3 times. Two times takeout and once inside. This last time they gave me burnt chicken which was really terrible. The other two times the food was okay. I get the lunch special with chicken and some sashimi. It's not too expensive and a decent place to eat but otherwise if it wasn't really close to my house id go somewhere else.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
I've been going to You See Sushi for years, pretty much when they first opened under McSushi and then became We Be Sushi (the original).  

I like them because of their simplicity.  They are a small mom and pop type place that keeps the menu basic and the prices very reasonable.  I love that I can get pieces of various sashimi in increments of threes...amaebi especially!  They offer simple bento boxes without all the craziness, which can be quite comforting when you want basic Japanese food or sushi.

Sure, they start you off with healthy carrot sticks and their miso soup has cabbage instead of seaweed and tofu.  But there's a reason they have been open so long, regulars like us appreciate the slight differences.  I love their huge mugs of tea and I like that their menu rarely changes, nor do the prices.  It's a comforting place.

Whenever I go, I usually stick to the sashimi and some nigiri - hamachi, sake, saba, amaebi, ikura, uni, albacore, etc.  Sometimes I'll throw in a roll to mix it up a bit, but I love my raw fish.  Other friends stick by their Dinner Special which to them means a lot of bang for their buck.  

It's one of my comfort places...and it's nice when the owners see you and recognize you.  One time I was shocked when the waitress commented on my haircut!  It had been awhile since I'd been there, but she remembered me.  Wow.
author: Teri C.

description:
If you are looking for cheap delicious sushi, this is the place to come!  They have a togo menu if your in a rush and you can find a verity of sushi rolls for under $5 that are decent portions.  My favorite thing to get here is the seaweed salad though :) I try and come here once a week to make it through the week!  

ENJOY
author: D R.

description:
[M]ona: 4 Stars
[W]ayne: 4 Stars
Average: 4 Stars

+ Super Affordable!!! 
+ Accepts Credit Cards
+ All Sushi are $8 and under

- Slow Service
- Lights were too low. Kept banging my head on it whenever I went to use the restroom.
- Bathroom sign should be written in English (Bathroom) instead of Japanese (Otearai)

[W] You See, this place is a pretty good spot for bargain sushi that's very tasty as well. You See is conveniently located close to a UC haha... lame joke... anyways we know I'm never going to aspire to be a comedian. Anyways, we always drive past here but never actually tried it until today and we were pleasantly surprised on how good the sushi tasted for its price. 

[M] Let's just say we had A LOT of choices to eat for $50 worth whereas if you were at the other sushi spot down a few blocks, you can only get around 4-5 rolls. Bleh~

We ordered the Tamago Nigiri, California Roll (real crab) Nigiri, Tobiko Nigiri, Uni Nigiri, Rainbow Roll, Futo Maki, 49er Roll, Hawaiian Roll, Philly Roll and Grilled Salmon Teriyaki Roll. 

[W] We originally got one order of Tamago, 49er roll, Philly Roll, Rainbow Roll, Tobiko, and the Hawaiian Roll. [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/8ed5eduh4zdLGn_y4cCLWA?select=8lqjzL2Dv8vaXA-w3yZUeA]
] I really enjoyed the Hawaiian roll which had avocado, and scallop topped with Salmon and a thinly sliced lemon. This was a really refreshing sushi roll and delicious as well. All the flavors blended in very nicely. The Tobiko (fish eggs) was really good as well. It tasted fresh and not packaged. I could taste the sweetness of the eggs so that was good. 

[M] The Philly roll was my favorite. The cream cheese wasn't overwhelming and it gave a nice separate flavor along with the avocado and salmon. The Rainbow Roll was ok. There wasn't anything extraordinary about it. IT was basically a california roll with salmon, white tuna, and avocado on top. The Uni Nigiri was not the freshest, but for the price of $2.90 you can't it better anywhere else.

[W] Last on our FIRST PLATE (haha yes we had TWO) was the Tamago. That one was a wow. We've tried Tamago at many places and not everyone can make it right. Rather it's just bland or they make it a little thicker to hide their piece that has no flavor BUT this place made it just right. It was sweet and yummy. It was actually so good that I had to order another one haha.

After the first plate, we were still hungry so we went for round two. Normally I would just say F-it and leave it as that but this place had such good value that we couldn't pass up trying the other stuff. So on our second plate, we ordered another round of Tamago, Philly Roll again for Mona since she loves that cream cheese, the California Nigiri Roll because the couple next to us ordered it and it looked kind of good, Futomaki, and the Grilled Salmon Teriyaki Roll. [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/8ed5eduh4zdLGn_y4cCLWA?select=z-Dkab5w6Z3Kjcik5Ehbsg] Everything was delicious once again other than that California Nigiri Roll. The California Nigiri is one of those things that are better left to be looked at rather than eaten. 

[M] They could've used a tad more mayonnaise to give it some more tang in it because it tasted quite dry and flavorless in my opinion.

[W] Other than the food, once again the service is quite slow. I needed more tea (which just basically tasted like hot water) but I could NOT get any of the servers to get some so I had a plan, put my dirty plates on the table next to me and when they come to clean it up, I'll ask them for more tea... and it worked haha. 

Overall the food was pretty good but the service was sub-par. The dining room is pretty small so I don't see why they can't attend to all their clients. Our bill at the end came up to be 50 dollars and change. But like I said earlier, it was a GREAT value. A lot of items on the menu were around 3-4 dollars from what I can recall. Most places only give you a couple of rolls for that price including tax and we had a lot of food to try out. I would definitely come back again because of that reason. Parking can be problem here also because it can get pretty busy sometimes but today we got lucky.

[M] P.S. Thank you Jasmine for the super great recommendation for this place! : )
author: Mona C.

description:
Ive ate here a couple times and it was always good.  Nothing to write home about, but it has decent portions and friendly service staff.

Carrot sticks are cute. I'll be back when invited.
author: Andrew V.

description:
Why do so many people come here?  Because it's next to UCSF.  Undeniably, I come here from time to time because of its close proximity to school.  But in fact, the food here is subpar and a bit on the salty side.  The sushi, when made, is on the messy side--and not very presentable.  The fish isn't that fresh either.  I'm surprised I haven't gotten sick yet!  OK--that's not much of a worry since most of the sashimi/sushi fish you get here in the US is fairly safe (from tape worms and such!)

But really... would I come here to bring someone on a date?  Probably not.  It's close, and yes--it is cheap, but you get what you pay for.  The service is so-so and is VERY slow.  But hey, what can you do?  The only wait staff is the owner herself, so you have to give her a break.  But, during busy hours, it might be nice to have an extra waitstaff to help bring out dishes and take orders.  

I usually come here for lunch, so the beset deals are the bentos/combos.  Nothing fancy or out of the ordinary--chicken teriyaki, cali rolls...that sort of thing.  It's definitely the place to go for students--so, yes--you'll see lots of young students and their backpacks all around.
author: Matthew L.

description:
Umm where's my green tea???! 

My friend and I literally sat in the small restaurant and was left unattended for at least 10 minutes before anyone came to ask us if we would like tea. I'm not a tea Nazi but sheeesh! A little attention please!

We ordered a variety of rolls and some nigiri (see pic). Everything was mediocre if not yucky. Definitely dissatisfied. The price was fairly cheap but never again. One word to sum it all up: bleh!
author: Jeanne L.

description:
It is convenient for UC employees and the patrons around the neighborhood.

Food is decent.  Prices have gone up since back in the day when you would say it is affordable....now - I would walk a little farther for better quality for the price.

SERVICE SUCKS!  They are friendly, but 2 little women cannot handle lunch time rush.

They also do not know how to gauge phone orders. When you say the order will be ready in 20 minutes, but it isn't ready until 40 minutes since you were supposed to pick up - then say it take 1 hour!  People are planning their lunch breaks around that.

Balancing the customers dining in when take orders is a must!

In addition, today - they messed up with 2 take orders in addition to mine.  The sushi chef even had to come out and help figure it out! They gave someone else's order - so someone is eating what he didn't expect.
author: JJAMZ C.

description:
Came in for lunch , it wasn't too crowed so got a table immediately but pretty much everyone else was med students so see what people are saying about a rush. 

The service was great. I got the lunch sushi #2 but the food could have been better.

The miso and rice was great, the spicy roll was not made fresh and you could tell it was sitting around a little bit. The Negiri pieces did not look to nice and also did not taste how good sushi should.  I prob am not going to go back.
author: Max S.

description: Nice portion of food in the Bento Box. Delicious.  Love the sesame seeds on the chicken to give it a crunch. Salad n sashimi was fresh! Great food. Great service.
author: Valerie S.

description:
You see, the sushi rolls here are cheap. Like, priced at $8 or less cheap.

You see, the sashimi here is affordable. Like, you can pay $10 and get twice the amount you regularly get at other sushi joints in SF. 

You see, the green tea here is free. Like, we even got refills without asking our server.

You see, the food here just didn't do it for me. Okay, maybe the chicken teriyaki bento box but even then it would be something not worth driving here for.

You see, I wish you well but you won't see me coming back here again.
author: Janice C.

description:
I grew up one block away and I've been eating here since they opened when I was a little kid (We Be!).

The sushi rolls are good, the sashimi is absolutely fresh (read: edible), and I like their little green salad with dressing. One nice thing about eating in is the big 'ol mug of endless green tea they bring you. Its very comforting. 

The ambiance is intimate and casual.

This place is also pretty cheap!
author: Catt G.

description: This place is like my favorite mediocre sushi. Had to give it a 3 star so people don't have the misconception of this place being a legit sushi restaurant. It's like the easiest 3 star I've ever given. When I'm in the mood for California rolls and dragon rolls, this is the place to go. Super cheap and efficient. If you're looking for fresh sashimi, and the perfect combination of vinegar and sugar for the sumeshi, you're in the wrong restaurant.
author: Cody M.

description:
If you want cheap sushi, you come here.

I never have to wait, to go orders are quick and eating in just as fast. Quality? You get what you pay for. Koo is just down the street if you're looking for an amazing sushi meal. You See Sushi's service is always on point and all in all, it's a satisfying meal. I've always just ordered their rolls and they are decent for such an affordable sushi joing.

The key is to go in with no expectations and you'll be pleasantly surprised. You'll have to street park and that shouldn't take too long.
author: Rosa L.

description:
Erh, kind of fishy.  I can pack in some sushi, but I could not finish the tuna roll in my dine-in sushi lunch because it was just too fishy tasting.
This is not the place to come if you are a sushi lover craving sushi.  I kind of knew this coming into this place, and my suspicion was confirmed.
author: Missy S.

description:
If you're on a budget, this is a decent place to go for sushi. 

Being so close to UCSF, you wouldn't think the quality would be that great, but it's really pretty good.  The fish is relatively fresh and the price is right.

I was craving sushi this past weekend and that always adds up, so we decided to try You See Sushi.  We didn't eat there, but called in our order and picked it up.  There was a ton of parking everywhere during prime weekend dinner hour, but it might have been because it was a rainy night.

Try the Lady in Red.  It was yum!
author: Kris L.

description:
Very inexpensive and convenient location for anyone involed with UCSF medical center.  

The sushi is nothing to write home about but you can get your wasabi fix cheap and fast.  Nothing we had there was bad nor was anything astounding.
author: Meg M.

description:
I'm really not a dick nor an avid reviewer but was very disappointed with their food. Ordered a rainbow roll and philly crunch rainbow roll. 

Philly roll was not crunchy rather  fairly soggy. Rainbow roll, oy vey!...where to begin. Fish definitely not fresh, awful texture and an insult to fish. Filling, yea it was a filling that was just bland. Cost about $20 and order takeout.

I live in the area and expected much better.
author: Josh V.

description:
Hmmm..a little puzzled by this place. I wish I'd gotten something different. I ordered a rainbow roll and edamame, and the edamame wasn't quite fully cooked and the rainbow roll just had imitation crab in the center, that's it, and then fish on the outside.
Because of this it barely even tasted like sushi, just tasted like....meh.
I guess other reviewers were right. It's just not good enough to go back despite the price. I have a dream I'll find sushi that's cheap AND fresh AND good, but,  besides Okina, which I've also reviewed, my dream may not be a reality .
author: Lauren C.

description:
Layout: A small but cute place with a home-y vibe to it. 

Walls neatly decorated; nothing too distracting to the eye. The atmosphere was very relaxed and the music was at an enjoyable volume. I want to emphasize that this place is very clean and well kept. No broken furniture, no chipped cups or utensils, no peeling walls, nothing out of place, nothing too gross or sticky I wouldn't want to be around. Bathrooms were clean too. 

Service: We were one of two tables this late Saturday night. Our party of 3 arrived half an hour before closing. Service was good and our orders came really fast! So did the bill. Even though we overstayed 20 minutes after closing they were not rude at all when they asked us to leave. Very nice staff tonight! 

Food: While waiting for our food, we were served Miso Soup with cabbage. I've never had cabbage as a substitute for seawood. Nonetheless still delicious. My order consisted of 3 rolls and a side. Futomaki, Philly Roll, Takuan Maki and Inari. I was so impressed with everything - what You See Sushi did was great. Actually, what I got was perfect! I was above satisfied with my order. All my rolls were cleanly cut and was made with such care! 

Final thoughts: Cheap food, great quality. I highly recommend this place and I will be coming back!
author: Melissa L.

description: Yummy neighborhood sushi joint. Very budget-friendly prices and good sushi lunch and dinner combinations. A good place to have lunch when you are at UCSF, which is just up the street. The room is somewhat small, so you may have to wait a little bit at rush times.
author: J L.

description:
Pros: accepts credit, lunch specials
Cons: Slow with tea/water refills, salty miso soup, yellowing lettuce salads, warm sushi

I came with coworkers for a lunch outing today around 11:30am before the lunch crowd came. We were seated right away at the four tables in the main dining room closest to the entrance. Our waitress gave us 5 menus for 7 people. We were given our soups that came with the lunch dishes and it was very salty miso. I really could only eat the cabbage out of the soup and take a few sips of the soup. Our food came out very scattered from each other. Instead of hot rice and cold sushi, I got cold rice and warm sushi. I did appreciate the generous amount of teriyaki children that came in the lunch bento box and the very spicy wasabi. The avocado in my California Roll was slightly yellow, and the flavor was a little flat for an avocado. My supervisor ordered some rolls for the table to share, and I felt that the spicy tuna roll pieces were very small compared to the rainbow rolls. I would probably order more rolls the next time I come here, but in the mean time, Bento Box #1, is cheap and a nice filling light lunch.
author: Alex T.

description:
Its pretty hard to find a cheap yet decent japanese restaurant anywhere, especially in the city, but this place meets up to those expectations. 

I came here with my best friend for lunch on a ridiculously hot Friday afternoon. We walked in a little before 12 and it was so stuffy and humid in there, but none the less, there were about 2 other people in the restaurant but within the next 25-30 minutes, it got PACKED which didn't help the heat what so ever. Anyways, my friend and I both got their lunch special that came with 15 piece of tempura, 5 or so slices of raw fish and rice. It was HUGE for about $10. Lets see you find that much for that price at any other Japanese restaurant around the city! 

It's a great place to go if youre looking for some cheap and filling Japanese food!
author: Jennifer L.

description: When I am desperate for some BASIC, subpar and salty sushi and for also some soggy tempuras near UCSF campus, I go for their lunch special between 11:30am and 2pm, which costs around $7. It comes in handy especially if you are a busy UCSF student/employee, looking for a convenient hunger quencher besides Milberry Union food court. I mean it's a healthier option than Panda Express so I'm grateful it's here.
author: Mark Y.

description:
Cute place, cute name.  Pretty good sushi for the price range.

AMBIANCE: [****]
Clean, small, intimate. Nothing fancy, but it really doesn't need to be.

FOOD: [****]
*Miso Soup ($2.30) 
YUM. To me, one of You See Sushi's biggest standouts is actually their miso soup. It can be hard to find miso soup with the perfect balance of robust saltiness and subtle  underlying flavor, but this place nails it. Love the addition soft tofu and tender cabbage. This soup makes miso happy on a cold, foggy, Sunset night.

*Spinach with Sesame ($4.05)
Simple and delicious. Tender, nutty, sweet, salty, and ever-so-slightly bitter. Cold and refreshing.

*California Maki with Tobiko ($5.70)
The classic California roll on steroids! It almost does not have to be said how good simple crab+avocado+rice+seaweed combo is, but I must mention that the addition of ocean-y tobiko (fish roe) on the outside brings this roll to a whole 'nother level.

*Lady in Red Maki ($11.45)
I seriously need to find out who this lady in red is, because the sure has something good going. Her sushi taste, I mean. The roll consists of spicy tuna, avocado, and green onion wrapped with the usual rice and seaweed and topped generously with tuna sashimi and a drizzle of spicy mayo. Bam! So good!

Overall, this place is exceptional in the realm of weeknight sushi. However, don't expect the whole omakase, fish-flown-in-from-japan, bow-as-you-enter type of experience you get at a top-of-the-line sushi spot. You See isn't that, but it is damn good at what it does.
author: Luke H.

description: I came here after a long work day and was craving sushi and this place was on my walk home so I go there to order to go. The place was small, and the staff wasn't super friendly. Once I got home to eat my sushi it was super fishy tasting and definitely not fresh. YUCK! Won't be coming back here again.
author: Ranna K.

description: I was really disappointed in You See Sushi. As others mentioned, the sushi isn't very fresh or high quality. I was hoping the price would at least be low, but this mainly applied to lunch boxes. The Nigiri was typical prices and not worth it.
author: S D.

description:
My friends and I came here exactly at 5.

Service: Nothing out of the ordinary...friendly? I guess...It was just...average. lol. Although the waitress did constantly refill our tea so that was a nice gesture.

Food: We got the Alaskan, SF roll, Salmon roll, Caterpillar roll, Uni and two unagi handrolls. All the rolls were pretty average. Good, but not overly good.  Like I said before, it was just...meh. I've had better.  The unagi handrolls were overly sweet cause they doused it with kabayki. Too much for my taste. If they added cucumber, it would've balanced out the sweetness.  Also, the seaweed seemed kind of old.  It was very chewy. My friend was saying she was getting some jaw exercise.   I experienced my first Uni sushi. It was very....fishy. Did not like it at all. The wasabi was suppose to cut out the fishy-ness but...it didn't.

I feel like it was overloaded with msg. I had around 3 glasses of tea cause I was so thirsty. I've never had to drink so much water. Not my cup of tea.

Ambiance: The restaurant was really quaint and very cozy. It was pretty empty when we went.
author: Denise L.

description: I am going to sound like such a fatty but whatever.  My fellow yelpers don't judge! (hopefully).  I came here as a pre-dinner snack because I was too hungry to wait for my friends to go to Pomelo (which is right next door).  The service is great.  Very attentive and quick.  And the restaurant itself is very small and quaint.  I ordered seaweed salad, sake, and Lady in Red roll (spicy tuna/avocado wrap tuna and green onion).  Yes, that's a snack for me.  Don't judge.  I must admit, pretty decent quality fish!  It's no Koo but it does the job
author: Tammy N.

description: Came here over a year ago with my friend who lives and goes to school in the city. We were strapped for time so we plopped into the closest sushi place we could find after the lunch rush hours. I'll have to be honest and say that the sushi here is very forgettable. We ordered about 4 different rolls (can't remember which) but they were very measly and unappetizing. The staff here is very nice however so i would like to give them a 3 star but i feel like that would be an injustice to the quality of the food.
author: Elway K.

description:
Pretty decent quality sushi for one that operates as an ecomically-priced one.  I think it's better than what I recall from years ago when this was a We Be Sushi.  They appears to have a good selection of sake in addition to the variety of sushi.

I came here yesterday for an early lunch at 11:30am and was the second one to occupy a table.  By the time I left, the place was full and many were waiting for a table outside.  Apparently they attract many customers from the nearby UCSF campus during the lunch hour.
author: H K.

description: This place is awesome! Their location from UCSF makes it a perfect place to get a quick bite. You can also call in your orders to save time. The service is great and their food tastes pretty good. Their prices are also extremely fair which keeps me coming back (yep I'm a cheap/broke student). The only down side is that their rolls are kinda small and their chicken teriyaki doesn't always fill me up but it tastes really good so and I guess I should be grateful that I'm not stuffing my face with huge portions and giving myself food coma.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
This place is decent, you can't expect high quality sushi when they are charging such cheap price. But honestly, I don't feel like the price is that cheap... it just isn't expensive.

I had the tempura udon, which was pretty good. The soup was well flavored and the tempura was okay. I was a bit disappointed with the variety of tempura, they only gave me two shrimp, two cucumber or zucchini (not sure what it was cause i hate both and gave it to my grandma), and 3 carrots. 

Now for sushi that I stole from my sister and grandma. I tried the spicy tuna roll and the shrimp tempura roll. They  were good, but nothing special. The spicy tuna was not spicy enough.
author: Alicia W.

description: Awesome sushi! Great price. I work at UC so it couldn't be more convenient and delicious for the price. get their specials!
author: Siva M.

description: I have been coming here for years because they have decent sushi and sashimi lunch specials. They definitely catch a lot of the UCSF crowd due to their proximity to the campus. I much prefer Kiki's to this place. Whatever you do, AVOID ordering their chicken teriyaki. They serve it with a lot of skin and they burn it to a black crisp. I told the waitress that I wasn't happy with the chicken, and she could've cared less. I won't be going back.
author: Lia B.

description:
On a reserved Halloween, I am dressed up as a sushi addict.  With a chef robe, wasabi as my neck, soy sauce (low sodium, of course) dripping from my corner lip, and chopsticks in my left pocket (usually contains a calculator), I trek down memory lane and write about a hidden gem. 

As a sushi addict and founder of SA (sushi anonymous), I craved sushi yet my recent financial advisor would think otherwise.  Not wanting to settle for SPAM on a Friday night, my choice would be a neighborhood joint.

Despite the financial climate, it is still possible to enjoy great sushi at a budget.   Located on a sliding slope in the inner Sunset, the husband-wife team of Paul and Ikuko have been serving vibrant dishes at neighborhood prices.  

Opened since 1991, the restaurant name reflects their main target audience: students and staff from University of California-San Francisco.

Light wooden table, miniature spotlight, and a scenic nature painting all add to a cozy ambiance.  All the times I have dined there, service is attentive in the thirty seat restaurant.  

Once seated, a cup of carrot sticks are served.  Dressed in a casual attire, the wait staff promptly takes the order.  With my assortment of nigiri and rolls, the food arrives resembles a colorful canvas.  Like a symphony, each sushi carries a special note and tone.

Nibbling on a few slices of ginger to refresh my plate, one bite into the buttery hamachi (yellowtail -$2.15) started the meal.  The blushing red maguro (tuna-$2.15) has a great sea-sweet taste.  For a taste of one of the oiliest fish, the saba (mackerel -$2.00) does the trick. Changing to a sweet note, the unagi (eel-$2.15) brushed with tangy sweet teriyaki glaze is worth another order.  

The uni (sea urchin-$2.90) is my comfort food order.  With a creamy nutty note, uni displays a fresh fishy acquired taste.   With translucent meat, the ameibi (raw shrimp-$2.90) demonstates the goodness of raw seafood.  

A mound of small eggs wrapped in nori creates the tobi (flying fish roe-$2.15). Known as the "dessert sushi", the tamago (egg omellete-$1.80) rounded out a great meal.  

-- 

**Side bar**
Opening scene, you're on a date (hot or cold date no matter) who happens to be a food snob, 

Impress your dates w/ some sushi notes.

Not only is sushi delicious, but also has many health benefits.  Generally, sushi is low in calories.  Rich fish such as tuna, mackerel, and eel have less than 200 calories per 3.5 oz.  

Mackerel and herring are oily fish known to be high in mega-3 fatty acids, which have been known in decreasing the chances of heart disease, stroke, and arthritis.  

As an excellent source of protein and carbohydrates, rice is not only gluten-free but also suitable for diner with wheat allergies.  Known to help prevent cholesterol deposits from building up in blood vessels, nori (seaweed) contains rich vitamins such as A, B1, B2, B6, niacin and C.  

Aiding digestion and rich in vitamin C, wasabi also has antibacterial properties.  Helping the body to fight colds and flu, ginger boost the immune system.  Rice vinegar has been used to preserve food but also lowers the risk of high blood pressure.   

__ 

back to review.

Served with fresh crispy seaweed, the make (sushi rolls) are great as well.  Those who enjoy a taste of fusion Japanese food, the 49er, dragon, and tempura rolls are great picks.  

Pairing well with the fresh raw fish, the hot sake (regular-$2.75) warmed my palate.  

While there are a mile long list of Japanese restaurants in the city, patrons have returned mainly on the price along with quality.
author: Rayfil W.

description: The lunch special #2 got you 10 pieces of sushi for 7 bucks which was alright. I got the chicken teriyaki with sashimi as well because I eat a lot and that combination hit the spot. The place is small so I would consider calling in an order for lunch instead of waiting in line because I'm usually in a hurry to finish lunch.
author: Dang T.

description:
This place is the shiznit!

Their sushi isn't the best around.

Their atmosphere is nothing fancy.

But when you want quick, affordable, tasty, sushi without lines - come to You See Sushi.

Richard and I stopped in here after a long day. I'd heard mixed things about You See Sushi, so I was apprehensive. My concerns were put to rest once I glanced at the prices. Some of the best in the city.

We ordered 6 rolls. Many of them elaborate. The standout was by far the spider roll. No fishy taste - just warm crispy crab, intermingled with fresh vegetables. 

And the total price? - $27.00. Um. Can you think of anywhere else in the city where you can get 6 fresh rolls for that price?

I think not.
author: Jessica T.

description: Teriyaki Chicken Bento. Salmon skin maki roll. Delicious.  Reasonably priced.  Nice people.   And money left over for Enzo Angiolini boots.
author: Sheila S.

description:
Large sushi selection, very fresh and good sushi, low prices! I highly recommend You See Sushi for both takeout and dine-in. I always had good experience with their customer service and you can get a lot of sushi for little money. 

I wish that You See Sushi would deliver, and overall this is one of my favorite restaurants for sushi in SF.
author: Magdalena Z.

description:
Good, Fast and Cheap. Normally you only get two of the three, but on our recent visit we had them all.  Not that we were rushed but had great, cheap sushi.  The special  was unagi, avacado roll  (6 pieces), shrimp tempura roll (6 pieces),  4 pieces of Nigirl.

Happy they took care and made sure mine was Gluten-Free.
author: Bo D.

description: Amazing for the price. $5.95 lunch special - chicken teriyaki so good. Cheap delicious sushi! Small cute space.
author: Andrew K.

description:
You See Sushi?

Psh, More like You See hella tiny rolls of rice wrapped in seaweed with a microscopic piece of filling inside. The only reason why I'm not only giving one star is because it's pretty dirt cheap and it made the kid that I babysit happy to have sushi.

Also, the moment we sat down the waitress comes up and goes "Are you ready to order? Cuz we're closing"

RUDE. 

and when we ordered she goes: "ok thanks, this will be the last order ok?"

ALso, did i mention that 
IT WAS 2:00 pm!

CHeap ass place with even cheaper ass sushi. Will only come back if i'm desperate and only have 2 dollars in my hand.
author: An-Nhien L.

description:
i really like their lunch special #2. almost get that every time i go! 

this place is great for ucsf students who are busy with school or just too lazy to cook during midterm seasons.
author: Louis O.

description:
On top of being a very good low key Japanese restaurant the service was absolutely perfect .
Way over exceeded our expectations 
Thank you !
author: julien b.

description: What was that one quote?? "You pay for what you get???" Well, I only paid $15 for a DUFFLE BAG FULL of yummy fresh SUSHI! Im sure I wont get this anywhere else with the chump change i pulled out of my jean pocket ! I came here for lunch because I had work at UCSF that day and decided to yelp places nearby... I'm a sushi lover therefore, i came here. I ordered a bunch of nigiris and also a goma ae (spinach salad) on the side. Everything tasted fresh! The only down side was... NO PLUM WINE?? noOOoO...... But its okay, stilll worth giving 5 stars (: Definitely will be back if I work at UCSF again ,
author: Annie Y.

description: Best sushi for the value.  Our kids love the avocado rolls.  We are here almost every week or at least two - three times a month.  Teriyaki chicken is good.  Good lunch and dinner specials especially for the price.
author: Phil T.

description:
If you are looking for a sushi restaurant with the "authentic Japanese" atmosphere, this may not be your place.  If you are looking for quality sushi at very reasonable prices, You See Sushi is for you.
The service is great and the staff is very friendly.   I haven't had a roll here that I didn't like, but the You See Special is a great deal and definitely my favorite.
author: Grant M.

description: The sushi and sashimi are only GOOD. But the place is so clean, bright, kid-friendly, efficient and cheap. Hard not to love it. The lunch specials are really inexpensive, tasty, and generous. Kids loved the teriyaki chicken--it was probably the best I've ever eaten. Pleasant service.
author: Michael D.

description:
get the sushi special. I saw a sign that said the following: 

Sushi special: ($9.95) 
4 pieces of nigiri sushi: tuna, salmon, white tuna, red snapper 
6 pieces of eel & avocado roll 
6 pieces of fried shrimp roll 
comes with miso soup 

so I thought it was pick one of the three for ~$10, which is pretty much how much a roll usually costs. But no i was wrong! it was ALL - 16 piece of sushi all for under $10. Can't really find another sushi joint in the city that can compete with the price and quality of this place (yes, cheap AND yummy sushi here!) 

Conveniently located near UCSF, this place is quite budget-friendly for the students. It's a hole-in-the wall with a minimalist approach to its decor...maybe that's why this place doesn't have to charge a premium to cover fancy schmancy overhead as a lot of sushi restaurants do. I can totally see why this place is popular!
author: Melody L.

description:
Went here for lunch on a Thursday afternoon. Got a sushi lunch special and two rolls. There is a list of lunch specials that are all $6. The rolls are an average of $4-5 for 6 pieces. 

-The lunch special I got was a 6 piece spicy tuna roll with 4 pieces of nigiri. Although the sushi was mushy and not the greatest, it was a decent meal with miso and rice for $6. Not bad. 
-The miso soup doesn't have tofu and seaweed like regular. Instead it has cabbage and carrots. But it was a nice tasty surprise. 
-I got a avocado eel roll. And a tempura cucumber roll. I forget the names but that's basically what was in it. The eel roll was good but it was a lot of avocado and very little eel. The tempura roll was pretty bland. But the rolls were only $4 each. You get what you pay for. 
-Whole bill came to $16 and it was a pretty good amount of decent food.
-Service was pretty good. Although the restaurant was a little jammed, close quarters.
-Parking around the restaurant is a 2 hour time limit. But You See Sushi is more of a eat and go place. Hence being near UCSF.

Just for the price, I'd go again. Its extremely good value but the quality is lacking. I'd recommend You See Sushi for the bargain. It's a great lunch spot for those on a budget.
author: Aron L.

description:
2.5 stars. Yes, I've experienced better, but that doesn't mean I won't eat it. Everything's relative, right? 

I feel like the quality of sushi at any given japanese restaurant can fluctuate a lot, so it's hard to put a meaningful rating on this place for its fish. The yellowtail I've had here was decent enough. Somewhat mealy, but not unfresh. So I guess I can go off the chicken teriyaki. The teriyaki sauce I'm assuming is some bottled stuff, but it's pretty good. For some reason, whenever I've gotten the chicken, it comes out all hacked to pieces and I don't mean nicely sliced chicken breast, but tiny bits of chicken that looks like they were scraping it off the grill. The california rolls are ok. 

Price for a lunch special, which comes with miso soup and salad, is $5.95 with several options. They serve green tea, which is nice and soothing on a cold day. Service is quick, seating is not too bad. 

It's a cheap, no frills sushi place.
author: Saunders C.

description:
I was here this past saturday and It was awesome! I don't live here in the bay, so my friends that live in the bay took me. 

I had a dinner combo that consisted of 5 pieces of fish and a spicy tuna and a cucumber roll all for 9.95! You can't beat that. The fish was really fresh too. 


Free green tea!

Service was great and accommodated my party of 12. 
Service was fairly quick as well. 


Saki and beers are super cheap as well.  

If your looking for a good value for sushi then you should definitely  come here.
author: Priscilla L.

description: Great customer service, though I went with a long time local. The food is fresh and stellar, with prices to match. The place recently expanded and it is great to see the funky atmosphere. It is just fresh, good food with a lo key and welcoming staff.
author: Natasha M.

description:
The sushi here is okay, but for the price, it is GREAT.

I was visiting a former coworker at Parnassus and she suggested we go since I'm so budget constrained (I blame UCSF and a few other med schools for the fortune they made me spend in the rejection process). I was not disappointed. For $5.95, I got a spicy tuna roll with avocado plus 4 pieces of nigiri, miso soup, and a bowl of rice. Even with my huge appetite I was full, had a lovely time, and got out of there with an unharmed bank account.

I won't be frequenting these parts again anytime soon but it's nice to know that a good deal exists in the city.
author: Kara R.

description: Great sushi for your $$.  Not the best cut shashimi or fanciest rolls, but when the bill is half the price of Ebisu and no line ever it became our go to place for weekly sushi.  Definitely give it a try, especially if you and watching your pennies
author: Chris J.

description: Pretty mediocre sushi. I got the sushi set with teriyaki chicken and california roll and it was decent. We came a little before 12 so seating was fast since we beat the lunch rush. Overall, if you want something close to UCSF campus and with relatively fast service then come here.
author: Diana N.

description:
