When small intimate research teams want to live a little go buck wild at You See Sushi for your monthly lunch meetings instead of the drab boring dark conference room where you typically eat your lunch.

Ok so it's no 3 star Michelin place, but come on, $7 for rice, miso soup, tea, some rolls and sashimi? I'd say this was great! Perfect for when you've got an itch for some Japanese food but can't go balls to the walls on a 2 hour $40 excursion. 

The rolls aren't too crazy (which I prefer), and there's enough variety on the menu if you're not in the mood for sushi but still want Japanese.
author: Monica D.

description: This is the best place. We love the food, the quality, the small, intimate space, and most of all, the FRIENDLY, helpful service. It's our favorite spot. Try their udon (simple and light), vegetarian rolls (add green onion to an avocado roll, trust me), and the most delicious miso soup in the city.
author: Osh J.

description:
The sushi here is good, not great, but good. And GREAT for the price. 

Prices here are about HALF of what you would pay at most other sushi restaurants in the city. The quality isn't super impressive but better than many places with much higher prices. Service isn't great, it was difficult to get my water refilled.
author: Kelly Kate W.

description: Let's be real... For the price..This place is bomb! Love the shrimp tempura roll and their teriyaki chicken is amazing. If on a budget and craving some sushi, this place has your back!
author: Caitlin S.

description:
This place is excellent, the staff is very attentive and friendly.  The sushi is delicious and the presentation is top notch. They are very accommodating and the lunch specials are unbeatable.

It is a clean and comfortable space, the music is not overbearing and neither is the lighting. Overall, I'd say it's a great spot to be a regular, I know I'll definitely be going back and soon!!!!
author: B K.

description:
Well, it's cheap, and...did I mention it's cheap?  

$5.95 lunch special includes a cut roll, 2 nigiri and miso--not bad.  We just opted for 4 cut rolls a la carte totaling something like $18.  Needless to say, the hot, gray, split-level dining room was not designed for a fancy sushi night out--it's designed for hungry lunch folks who don't have time (or money) to fuss much.  And if that's you, then You See (UC, get it?  There are lots of people dressed in scrubs here) will work fine for you.  But if you're looking for quality, there's plenty of better options all over the Sunset.
author: Wes M.

description: Awesome sushi lunch special!  $6 gets you soup, rice, spicy tuna maki, and 4 pieces of nigiri that you can substitute to your liking.  To my pleasant surprise, the fish was exceptionally fresh and more or less achieved melt-in-your-mouth status =D
author: Eric F.

description:
Lunch special is a good value at $5.95 for spicy tuna & avocado roll,
nigiri albacore, salmon, yellowtail & mackerel.  Sushi portions are small but yummy, had to fill up by eating the bowl of rice.
author: Elsie D.

description: Been eating here for 3 years and is my absolute go-to weekly takeout sushi spot in the Inner Sunset! Their crab in their rolls is really delicious and definitely stands out compared to other sushi restaurants. I recommend everything... but I always get their Soup, Seaweed salad, Cucumber salad, Hawaiian maki, and the Dragon roll....also, their Prawn/veggie Tempura is always light and crispy and not greasy! Very delicious.
author: Leslie A.

description: Love this quaint little sushi place! I wish the prices didn't go up after they remodeled because the previous prices were perfect, but I guess times change. They always have great specials that are good deals, and the sushi is always delicious.
author: Ganesha B.

description: Really great prices, pretty decent sushi.
author: Audrey K.

description:
dear you see sushi,

your chicken teriyaki lunch special is cheap.  you get what you pay for.  but i would appreciate it if you can leave out the chunks of charcoal...what? oh, that's the chicken? my bad.

sincerely,
burned
author: Sally T.

description:
Any place in SF where I can get a tasty sushi meal with soup and tea for about ten bucks has something major going for it.  Throw in the fact that their warm dishes are also tasty and equally inexpensive?  WIN!

You See is great for lunch or dinner.  I've heard amazing things about their veggie sushi from vegetarian friends but I usually stick to the You See dinner special.  I don't like eel and the staff always lets me swap it out for something else - no surcharge, no attitude, no problem.  

It's not jaw-dropping sushi (see: zushi puzzle), but it is a tasty meal to satisfy your sushi craving when you don't want to spend a lot of money.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
I think this is one of SF's best value for sushi.

I've been coming here for probably 7-8 years and they have remained consistently good. Sure, it's not mind-blowing sushi, inventive or flawless. But it is always fresh and affordable. The complimentary carrot sticks when you sit down is  a nice touch.

The service at times can be a little less than warm and welcoming, but I always leave full and enjoy everything that I order. The best part is the price. My husband and order loads of nigiri, sashimi, maki and specialty rolls,  drinks and miso and somehow the bill is never more than$40. For sushi in SF-it doesn't get much better. It's casual, easy and good and I never am disappointed.
author: Lindsay H.

description:
I never thought there would be a tasty, yet cheap, sushi place. If you want to go eat good sushi, and not hear your wallet crying after the bill, this is the place! 

The meal combinations are good, and pretty filling. The sushi is fresh and very tasty. 

Though most of the waitresses there are very pleasant, there was one who was rather rude. Aside from that, it is a great place to eat at!
author: Bianca W.

description: Fairly good sushi - the dinner specials are actually what you might expect to save you money, unlike some places where the specials are the priciest things on the menu.
author: Amber Y.

description: Excellent sushi the dinner special The best quality and price very good
author: Herve L.

description:
This place is awesome. Always great prices, they have beer and sake, and the sushi is fresh and good.

If you're in the area, definitely check it out if you like sushi.
author: Chris L.

description:
This is a great place to go if you're in the mood for Japanese food but you are on a budget! My roommate and i were debating on going to Kiki's on 9th but we decided to try out You See Sushi because it was closer to our apartment!

It was a fun little restaurant with a friendly atmosphere. Even though the food took a while to come out, it was a nice experience. The table was also a little bit sticky  but it wasn't because of food... it seemed like it was from some sort of glue or... i don't know but it didn't seem unsanitary. it just gave me a reason to work on my posture! =)

I had hot tea to drink which they refilled often.While we were waiting they provided carrot sticks for us (nice surprise!).  For dinner I ordered the veggie tempura dinner combination. It came with salad, miso soup, rice, Vegetable tempura and three avocado cucumber rolls ($6.95). It was great! I was super hungry though so i also ordered avocado maki ($1.85) and shiitaki maki ($2.45). Each of those came with 6 rolls.

My roommate ordered the mixed veggie maki (big roll $3.95) and it was really good! I was lucky enough to try one of them! She also ordered the soft shell crab maki ($4.95) which she thought was good. I would definitely go back!
author: Anthony H.

description: Fish quality is hit or miss here. Service is also hit or miss. Have been before by myself and had decent food and service. Recently went back and had the wrong dish delivered, all five of our sushi and sashimi plates delivered and 20 minutes later got our edamame, and fake pink-dyed tuna. Live very close but likely will not go back with other good options in the neighborhood.
author: Alana S.

description:
There was only one lady serving all the tables when we walked in to this little place so I was a little worried when we sat down. She seemed rushed and brusque but understandably so, since she was super busy so I brushed it off.  
The food is a really good value here. I've definitely had worse for way higher prices. I had bento combination and a few nigiri which tasted pretty fresh, and some hot tea. Overall I was very satisfied, especially with my large mug of tea :) 
I'd definitely come back when I'm craving sushi and don't have a lot to spend. I love good deals!
author: Michelle R.

description:
Adorable. Unpretentious. Delicious. Inexpensive.

Hard to ask for more.
author: Natalie J.

description:
This place the best place to get cheap priced sushi!

They have very affordable sushi dinner specials. A little over $10 for a nigiri and sushi combo that can fill you up.  You also order the lunch special during dinner for around $7 if you're not that hungry. 

Most 2 piece nigiri is a little over $2.  Uni is only around $3 and it taste pretty good!

I love this place for the price! and the quality is very decent! 

But I have to admit, this isn't my #1 favorite cheap sushi place... but it might be my #2 or #3 fav.
author: Jannifer H.

description:
Thank you Yelp!

I love finding little gems like this!

This place didn't have the fanciest sushi in the world, but for how cheap it is i was pleased! I suspect if I ordered any of the fancier rolls though, it would have been very good though.

I got the dinner special which was SO MUCH food for $10.00! Two rolls (8 or so pieces each, i can't remember) and about 6-7 different pieces of unagi (sp?) , miso soup, and tea!?!?! for $10? Somebody pinch me!

This is going to be my new sushi spot in the city!
author: Chaslin S.

description:
Service was horrible. They had two people running it - from bussing tables to taking orders to settling the bill.

BUTTTT... the price was awesome for the food. I had the tempura udon for $6.95. They gave me quite a few pieces of tempura. YUMMM!!!
author: Sharon G.

description:
Okay, so I went back.  We were on the hunt for sushi and as we passed You See Sushi my friend said "Lets try it one more time.  If its bad again we will never go back".  

Against my will I went in expecting to have an awful dinner that I could later hold over my friends head for the rest of the night if not years to come.

Since that night , we have been back at least another 4 to 5 times.  I don't know if my first visit was just a bad night for them or for me, but the sushi has been awesome!  It's fresher than before and presented well.

The sushi chef always smiles, thanks us for coming and waves good-bye as we leave.  Looking at his friendly smiling face almost makes me feel bad about my first review - almost.
author: Stacy Y.

description:
As other Yelpers have pointed out this place has ridiculously cheap rolls!  So cheap I was astonished.  Go ahead, go to their webpage and check out their menu, it will blow your mind.  Okay, I may be prone to hyperbole, but they are cheap - $2.45 for spicy tuna maki; $7.50 for a Rainbow roll; $4.20 for Soft Shell Crab maki.  

As for quality, it was middle of the road.  Nothing special, but decently tasty.  Primarily, this will satisfy your sushi cravings without forcing you to moonlight as a panhandler.  We ordered six rolls and a "box" with tuna sashimi, tempura, salad and miso soup - our entire bill was $38.  

When I return, I'll definitely order the Soft shell crab roll, Rainbow roll and spicy tuna roll again.  I'd probably avoid the smoked salmon roll, saba roll and salmon skin maki - not because they were terrible, but because they were mediocre and there are other things to choose from.
author: Thor M.

description: Eh... The teriyaki chicken is nothing special, the rice was over cooked, the sauce thick. Overall I'd suggest trying a different dish.
author: Jason C.

description:
Good sushi and inexpensive price. 
I recommend Chicken Teriyaki.
author: Sutheerak R.

description: For the price you really can't beat this sushi. Is it the best sushi you've ever had? Probably not. But it's totally *good*, and the place is super clean. Nice staff, posi atmosphere and crazy cheap.
author: Mike G.

description: Great Sushi for a great price.  I ordered the #2 Sushi Platter with Rock and Roll Crunch.  Wow what a great deal!! Also ordered the chicken bento box with tempura everything was great.  As you walk in the specials are on a chalkboard to the right just in case you sit near the cashier.  The seats were perfect. Try not to sit in the main room cuz its sort of stuffy and the bathroom is right there.  I saw a couple sitting right in the path of the bathroom door.... no comment.  The price is right with decent sushi.  Its not foo sushi like other places and they get to the point.
author: Drew C.

description: I have been a customer for over 10 years.  They closed earlier this year to make changes and they are great changes.  The food is still awesome, the staff is still great.  It was not only nice to see the growth but to see all the crowds willing to wait for a table because the price is right, the food is great, the service priceless!
author: Karolyn H.

description:
I worked at UCSF for a couple years and the #C lunch special was one of my favorite dishes. Sushi was always on the OK end, but really like the bento box with the teri chicken (whole breast), 6 piece sushi, salad and rice. all and all a nice lunch for $5. oh... with miso and tea. If i find myself in the area i will usually stop if i don't go to park chow. and they always remember me and kinda joke but say... will you be having the #C? 

I always say yes. You should too...
author: Adam X.

description:
Il Buono: In expensive.  I ate here with Christina C. and only spent around $10.  The California rolls had real crab!

Il Brutto: Really bad miso soup with carrots.

Il Cattivo: The rice wasn't very good.  Low-quality fish (that's why I gota  California roll).

I guess if you really want sushi but only have $10, this place is OK.
author: Suo L.

description:
I used to come here a lot when my best friend used to live a few blocks away.  Nowadays, I never find myself in the inner sunset, and to tell you the truth, I don't miss it.  The Inner Sunset that is, not You See.

But, I will say that You See Sushi is pretty good for the price.  I saw some of the bad reviews saying that people got sick, they were served rotten sushi, ect.  So, a bit fearful myself, I looked on cleanscores.com to see their rating, and they've had great ratings since 2005, so I have a feeling those were isolated experiences and I felt bad, so I decided to advertise they've scored in the 90's for the past 3 years.  

I know, don't thank me.  It's 1:30am and I'm just procrastinating writing my Environmental Literature paper, so really you should pity me.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
The price for the lunch special is great - but on the other hand, it is expected that you'll get mediocre sushi. With me, I'd rather pay a little more for fresh sushi to optimize the culinary experience. I couldn't even distinguish the flavors between the eel and the yellowfish that well! If I ever go back and want to save a few bucks, I'll probably order the teriyaki chicken.

Update: Do not order the teriyaki chicken. The teriyaki sauce tastes cheap and synthetic.
author: Audrey L.

description:
sat down and the waitress came by with a cup of carrot sticks. what a totally random appetizer, i loved it!

this place is obviously not going for the most authentic, highest quality sushi award. there are a ton of cheap sushi places in the city and i was really impressed with this one. 

i was really pleased with the hamachi nigiri and the shiitake maki. next time i go, i'll definitely order those two again.
author: elsie k.

description: Let's just say it is what it is.. You See Sushi is definitely cheaper than most sushi places and the quality is just ok. I don't mind "ok" quality when the price is good. I came here on my lunch break last week and spent less than $10 on a filling lunch meal consisting of nigiri, rice, miso soup and tea. Not bad at all!
author: Emily C.

description:
I am so over amaebi.  But luckily I had one last go at it here.  

For lunch, I had the sushi combo A:
nigiri
california roll - with real crab! and not too much mayo
plus 1 order uni and 1 order amaebi.

I think the amaebi was a little bit opaque because they stuck it in something to defrost it.  The uni was exactly as I imagine $2.90 uni to taste like.

The other nigiri was just fine.  I don't like how they slather everything in the teriyaki/unagi glaze.  There was even a layer of it on the unagi.  Other than that, it was just right.  The unagi was crispy like it had just been broiled.  The other slices of fish were a little small, but for a $6 sushi combo, it was very generous.
author: Christina C.

description:
You See Sushi.... just a couple blocks below You See Ess Eff. 
(tee hee!!)

I truly LOVE a play on words!!!  I think it's hilariously dorky and cheesy!  Two thumbs up for cheekiness!!

I judge sushi places in two categories, are they trying to be:

Authentic? or Popular Tasty?

This place is Popular Tasty...I don't expect anything outside the norm of Cali Rolls, Teriyaki plates and funny named rolls. 

That being said there are two knocks for this place:

1) The Chicken Teriyaki was the fattiest ChickTer I have ever had at a sushi place.  Not good.

2) They served cabbage and carrot miso soup...it tasted more like Chicken Broth Veggie Soup. Meh.

I think I'll go just for cheapot depot funny named rolls from now on.   Sometimes you just don't need it to be hella fancy and elite sushi.
author: Jay H.

description:
You can't get any better than this for the price.

This place doesn't have great decor, but the staff are super-friendly. When we were in there, the boyfriend ordered an Asahi and apparently the waitress thought he said "a sake." When she brought the sake he corrected her and they both had a good laugh over it. 

The quality of their fish isn't AMAZING, but it's fresh and it's decent and I've DEFINITELY paid much more for much worse. Even their drinks are cheap--$1 for a soda, which is, sadly, pretty remarkable for a restaurant. 

In summation: They're ridiculously cheap and very yummy. Too bad I won't often have an excuse to be in that part of town to visit again!
author: Lynae Z.

description:
So you CAN get inexpensive sushi in the Sunset!  Sure, their rolls are not too original.  Sure, the service isn't too quick.  But the hot tea comes in really cute cups.  And you can order their lunch special A for dinner for $1 more.  And you'll be full and satisfied.

Yay for cheap sushi!
author: Jenny L.

description:
Good sushi for a great price? Hey, I'm there!

I just went here and the sushi was good. Nothing really special. 

I tried most of the nigiri sushi and I noticed the kick of wasabi that was hidden beneath the seafood! That sneaky bastard...Well at least it cleared my sinuses. LOL!

The special rolls were quite tasty. Loved the 49er roll and the Dragon roll! Good stuff! 

That sucked that they didn't have Uni! =( 

Very affordable and very nice people, but the parking sucks big time!!
author: Marc E.

description:
I see sushi all of the time from You See Sushi, it's a great place to have close by for a solid tasty affordable meal (heck I can't swing going to Koo all of the time :).  

We've been getting sushi and other dishes from here for some time and know that we can always rely on them for a very decent meal at a price that helps compensate for the more costly sins of other meals out. The quality is overall very good, but I do have to admit that I've had the occasional tad bit on the fishy side item; nothing that has ever had ill effects on me though.  

They do a good job of packing the 'to-go' bags with everything thoughtfully included; perfect for when you are too lazy/busy to cook and want to eat something healthier then a pizza.  A box crammed full of rolls from You See always brings a smile to my hungry self at the end of a day.
author: GIR ..

description:
My friend and I went here par is suggestion.  He had "Yelped" it before and dined here and said it was a sister restaurant from the Mission.  I was like, "You See Sushi...  it's an interesting name.  We Be Sushi?"  Then my friend was like, "Yeah, like U.C. sushi...  cuz it's right near the U.C. campus."  Ooooooooh!  Hahaha.  Yeah, I had a blond moment or as others like to say brain fart.

In any case, the service was nice and the fish that night was particularly fresh and the rice was done perfectly with an amazing consistency.  I enjoyed it very much for the price it came.  I definitely will go back and see if it was a fluke or if it will deliver like it it the other night.
author: Susan C.

description: Yeah! I found an inexpensive sushi place in San Francisco!  Its big, the waitstaff is friendly and helpful and the sushi was delicious.  And I left full from one order from the server's recommendation.  Granted I don't eat alot, but I actually had a doggie bag.  My girlfriends were all full too.  We will definitely be going back. Thanks!
author: Tracy S.

description:
Every day I drive to the gym, I roll up Parnassas and past You See Sushi. Finally, one day on my way back with my roommate, our stomach growling and the impending doom of WWIII should we not eat soon approaching... we decided to stop in for a quick bite and avert the crisis. 

You will all be happy to know, no one died that day... well, except for some fish. 

What a great find, cheap prices, great service, and lots of warm tea on a cold day. 

Definitely a repeater!
author: Jordan Y.

description:
Cute hole in the wall.  Friendly staff.
down the hill from UCSF
Inexpensive (lunch box specials)
Not too much variety 
Not too long of a wait for food
author: Stel D.

description: Maybe it's 3 star sushi (good but not amazing) but the price gets it the 4th star. Very quick and pleasant - maybe a little heavy on the wasabi for me.
author: Lisa K.

description: I used to come here all the time when I lived down the street from here, as long as you avoid the lunch time rush, the service is quick and the quality is good.  Downside is this place is super small and when I do come here during lunch the wait is ridiculous...but what can do you do about it.
author: Tony T.

description:
My boyfriend says he finally realized the pun of their name last night. I also didn't get it, even until he explained it to me. You See Sushi. U.C. Sushi. Ahhh, UC, like UC, next to UCSF. Now I understand.

The sushi was great for the price, the udon was not so good and only had like, 8 noodles. I noticed they don't have chicken katsu, which I happen to love. That was also disappointing. Their sushi mug for tea really made up for a lot, though, I have to say. 
When I want a big, luscious bowl of fat wormy noodles I will go to Hotei. Otherwise, this is a good, easy, inexpensive source for totally respectable sushi.
author: Colleen M.

description: Two rounds of sushi, soups, seaweed salad, and plenty of green tea cost me and two friends $40 after tip.  Sushi quality meets my expectations, especially for the price.  I enjoyed it so much since I could eat all the mackerel I wanted and didn't have to pay very much at all.
author: Alex S.

description:
It's a good place to eat on a tight budget. You'd easily miss this place if you weren't really looking for it. It's located right down the block from the UCSF campus so I guess that's why it's named You See. I went there for dinner with a friend. The place isn't too small, not very big either, and the decor isn't much to talk about except the restroom is unmarked, but has a sign next to the door in Japanese that says "Oterai" which means restroom.

For about $13 (tax and tip included) I got chicken teriyaki with rice, soup, salad, and 3 pieces of a California roll, and a Philadelphia roll. The teriyaki chicken isn't like most other places, it's better in my opinion. The sauce is thicker and it's slightly crunchy on the outside which I really liked. The miso soup is different too, instead of tofu and seaweed there's cabbage and carrots which makes the soup more hearty. The Philadelphia roll was the best I've had anywhere.

Although the portions were smaller on the entree it was definitely filling. The prices are cheap and the sushi is good. I know I'll be eating there more often when I start school at UCSF.
author: Felix T.

description:
After spending 3 hours at Nightlife at the Academy of Sciences (great place for a first date btw!), me and my date decided to head on over to You See Sushi. I've been here before and have quite liked it each time. The place is quiet, food is very good, VERY reasonably priced, service is quick and overall, its a great place to get good, tasty and cheap Japanese food. 

I ordered the dinner special with Teriyaki (comes with miso soup) and my friend ordered the California Roll special with eel rolls added. We both got Diet Cokes and desert and the final bill with tip came to $35... not too shabby! And we both were stuffed since the servings were quite big. Tea was nice too.

We got there at 935PM and they close at 945PM, but the owner was such a sweetheart and seated us and let us take our time ordering and eating. Of course, gentlemen that we both were, we scarfed our food down as fast as we could not wanting them to have to keep the place open any longer than needed. We left satisfied at 1015PM with a warm wave from the owner.

They also have excellent and quick take out. 

Too bad they are located on the odd street of Judah and 6th Avenue. The only other things there are Tikka Masala (indian food... no! really? with a name like that?) and Pomelo (love it!). But other than that, its a dead street. But the 6 Parnassus and 43 Masonic stop right by it, as does the N Judah a block down.

Other than that, its good for eating by yourself, with friends, looks like they can accommodate large groups. So, definitely try them out! They even have a "Recommended by Yelp" sticker on their door.
author: Amit S.

description:
The best part about this place are their lunch deals. Lunch deal D has a spicy tuna roll and a few bits of nigiri, miso soup and a side of rice, all for a nice value of $5.95. If you order take out - they won't include the rice, which means you'll end up more hungry. Just eat in when you can and drink lots of free tea.

If it were any more expensive, it wouldn't be worth going to.
author: Judy L.

description:
The first rule for eating here is not to expect the best sushi experience of your life.  Once you understand that, you'll be happy.  You See is one of those places that's consistently average.  Average in a good way.  I've never found anything I've ordered gross, funky smelling or inedible.  

Sometimes your mouth is craving sushi but your wallet won't allow for it.  You See will fulfill your craving without breaking the bank.  The dinner special at a whopping $9.95 plus another roll or order of nigiri easily feeds two.  It's not the best sushi but when two people can fill up for under $20 in The City?  Sign me up.
author: M M.

description:
Good sushi value in the Sunset.  

We're still spoiled by Yokoso Nippon, which has the best bang for buck on the Peninsula, but You See Sushi is an okay fallback if you're ever dying for sushi and can't make it over downtown.  It caters to mainly UCSF students, but you'll see the occasional sprinkling of locals like us.  

Their rolls are average-- nothing to write home about.  There's the usual solid assortment: dragon roll, 49er roll, spider roll, etc.   Prices range from $3-9 per roll (6 pieces).  

You get what you pay for so if you just want sushi and no frills, this place isn't half bad.  Just don't ask any UCSF student who thinks this place is overrated.
author: Kel S.

description:
You See Sushi provides average quality sushi at exceptional prices!  I've noticed a growing trend of rising prices among bay area sushi restaurants.  From Koo to Taraval Okazuya to Tokyo Express, I've frequently found myself walking out spending over 60 dollars on dinner for two.  I swear every time we get sushi, it gets more and more expensive.  You See Sushi, on the other hand, offered a nice respite from high priced sushi. Additionally the quality of the sushi was better than expected for the price.

We called in our order so that we could take it home to eat and watch a movie.  My gf and I love sushi, so we usually order an obscene amount, usually 40 - 50 pieces (most likely the reason sushi dinners are always so expensive for us).  We ended up going with Dragon and Rainbow rolls and various Maki rolls; California, New York, Tokyo, Karaino, Taekka and a few others.  We ordered 7 rolls for the two of us, sounds good!

We drove over to restaurant and I picked up the Sushi and it was only $32!  7 rolls for $32 dollars!  Wow!  Koo was 4 rolls for $75. So I was already happy with that.  The quality of the sushi was decent, the sashimi on top of the Rainbow roll tasted surprisingly fresh.  The one problem is that the rolls were a little small compared to other sushi restaurants.  We knocked out all 7 rolls with ease; usually we're stuffed to the max with that amount.  The California and Dragon rolls were average, nothing spectacular.  My favorite roll and one I'd definitely recommend is the Grilled Salmon Teriyaki roll with Avocado.  The salmon was cooked well, hot with crispy edges and drizzled with teriyaki sauce.  And it was only 3.95!  

I'm giving You See Sushi 3 stars because the price was there and the taste was decent.  However it was not at the level of other upscale sushi places in the city like Koo and Ebisu.  I'll definitely come back when I want a whole boat load of sushi and don't want to break the bank for it!
author: Timothy C.

description: Perfect for what it intends on being. A modest sushi restaurant that is easily accessible, inexpensive, and serves generous portions. I typically come here for lunch when I am at the Parnassus campus. I get the lunch special with either sashimi or the california roll. It hits the spot... especially for $6!!
author: Sirj G.

description: Great, inexpensive sushi! The service is really friendly. This intimate, cosy restaurant is a great place to grab a quick lunch or have a nice dinner.
author: Risa P.

description:
I went to You See Sushi for lunch yesterday (my first time). They served green tea without asking when I got there, and I just adore free stuff, so they were off to a good start!

I ordered the lunch special "D", which came with a spicy tuna/avocado roll, rice (with terriyaki-like sauce), miso soup, and four pieces of nigiri (albacore, mackeral, salmon and yellowtail). The fish was all fresh and delicious, and the price didn't break the bank at all (under $7). The  lunch specials are awesome, but I did note that if you're ordering them for take out, the order won't include soup or rice.

The restaurant is pretty small, so I wouldn't recommend going with more than a party of four. The staff was friendly, there was no wait, the food was fab, and the price was awesome. I'll be going back!
author: Chelsea S.

description:
Came here for lunch.
Ordered some spicy tuna sushi.
Verdict: Okay
author: A L.

description: Great for the price! Love the combo options; they have a nice variety of rolls.
author: Michelle G.

description: Extremely decent sushi at an incredibly reasonable price. Dinner specials include two specialty rolls, four pieces of nigiri and miso soup - all for under $10. Nothing fancy but a cute little restaurant with pleasant staff. We fed two hungry adults and two kids with a beer and drinks for under $50. We all walked away happy. Highly recommended!!!
author: Jodi O.

description:
1 hour limit for lunch and needed a quick bite with 2 very talkative former supervisors, so we walked down the street to this small sushi joint.  
Got seated in the next 5 minutes and had searing hot tea in front of us in the next 2.  We ordered 2 chicken teryaki bento boxes and tempura udon, all arriving at our table within 10 minutes. The chicken teryaki was a tad dry, but was smothered in sauce, I'm not a chicken eater, so I'm assuming its alright.  Iceberg lettuce with carrot and cabbage shreds smothered with too much soy sauce dressing, makes it seem like I'm eating straight sodium instead of a refreshing salad.  Tempura udon was wonderful with the exception of one thing, it came out scalding hot.  I only have so little time to eat it.  Noodles were perfectly cooked and the broth was a traditional with a sprinkling of benito flakes.  As a fan of tempura, their tempura is very well done, with a light airy batter and standard dipping sauce on the side.
With the little space that they have, probably pack the place with as many seats as the fire marshall will allow them.  That being said, its pretty much like eating in a tuna can.  If you lean back and stretch, you'd probably hit the person behind you.  With the little space in between the tables, everyone hears your conversations. This is not the place if you're going to lunch with 2 talkative Asian woman with marital problems. Consider yourself warned.
author: Van C.

description:
Prices are great. They're cheap, but the sushi itself looks like something I could make myself at home. The rice wasn't packed in nicely and overall it looked pretty sloppy. 

The bento box is really worth it. You get rice, salad, cali rolls or tempera, chicken teriyaki for like 10 bucks. And it's really filling. Once again the sushi is just decent, but if you're a cheap college student, this place is filling and cheaper than other places and will do the trick of filling your stomach.

They close pretty early though and they seem to kind of rush you when they're about to close which was pretty rude but what do you expect.

I'll admit the food came fast though and i was hungry so that was a plus.
author: Karen C.

description:
A nice, quiet, inexpensive place for sushi and comforting miso soup.  I too am unused to having carrots and cabbage in my miso soup, but ate it anyway.  I do enjoy miso soup, especially on cold days, and the strange vegetables neither added nor detracted from my miso experience.

I can't speak for any of the the shellfish, but the Alaskan roll, Philly roll, and the other ones we got (can't remember the names, but boy they were good--they involved unagi) were great.  Excellent prices, not too crowded, and you can get full without breaking the bank.
author: diana s.

description:
I don't highly recommend this place but this is a OK japanese place for UCSF ppl who don't want to walk all the way down to Irving (Ten or Ebisu). 

I always eat the Lunch Special Set D.  I haven't tried anything else because I don't think it'd meet my expectations.  This place is chinese owned so dont' expect the authentic japanese food.  Like I said before, you get what you pay for.  

I'll come here if I crave for some cheap sushi for lunch.
author: Kapo T.

description:
Friendly service.
Great prices.
Terrible food. 

It's really terrible food, I wanted to like it but it's awful, it felt like a low-end Chinese joint trying to pass as a mid-range Japanese sushi bar. Not worth it!

Check out the ornaments above the front door on your way out.
author: John W.

description:
My friend and I had a array of sashimi, which was fairly fresh nothing fancy it was laid on top of of some romaine lettuce. The staff was friendly and quick, although some of their choices makes me wonder....Their Miso soup was full of cabbages and not a speck of seaweed, also as soon as you sit down they give you a cup of carrot stick.....
This place is like crack, a cheap quick fix but will leave you yearning for more.
author: Andres K.

description: Go for the cheap prices and the yummy chicken teriyaki! It was great for breakfast the next day. Haven't tried the sushi, my whole table got the chicken and were yum-yumming about it still three days later. Soup, salad, cali rolls, rice and chicken teriyaki for dinner for under $10. AMAZING!
author: Ash W.

description: AHHH SUCH YUMMY SUSHI.. and soo affordable!!!  Came here for a quick dinner with a friend, literally the wait is soo short... had the dinner special 1 and 3 and two rolls with miso...and NO it wasn't just for me... all that food for  a lil over $15 per person wohooooo and I read that service wasn't that great and I agree the lady kinda grunted as we walked in but she warmed up and kept making sure my glass is filled with water ahhh... that deserved 4 stars itself... sushi's yummy ok nuff said!  BY THE WAY JUST GO BEFORE 9:30 last call for dinner is 9:45 or your S O L ahhaha
author: Ryan M.

description: Great neighborhood sushi bar.  Good food, relaxing, kid friendly, easy.!
author: Alison B.

description:
2 and a half stars.  I've had better, but it is really inexpensive!  Sorry, I've been a sushi snob for years and believe that good sushi has to be made at a real Japanese sushi bar.  I've tried other sushi bargain places, but I don't get the concept.  Sushi/sashimi should be savored in delicate, ridiculously fresh, bites. 

This place didn't even have a sushi bar, so you don't get to see the artistry in the preparation.  The rice seemed a bit loose.  Miso soup was strange with the cabbage.

I'm probably reviewing a bit hard, but I'm still looking for a replacement for Toraya - Fillmore.
author: Collin W.

description: their prices are very good, its HELLA cheap and have a variety of rolls for you to choose from.  I wouldnt say the over all quality of the sushi was great, ive tasted better BUT if you're craving sushi and on a tight budget, this is the place to go.
author: Chris C.

description: I have always loved You See! Everyone who works there has always been super friendly. The sushi is lovely and inexpensive. The carrot sticks are a nice app. Pour some soy sauce in that cup and yum!!
author: Brandy L.

description:
First, the plusses:  Not busy at all on a Wed night, attentive staff, good lighting, very reasonable prices

Now, the minuses:  Very mediocre sushi, portions that exactly fit the prices, muzak featuring elevator tunes that make you want to stab yourself in the eye with your chopsticks

I probably won't be back here.  The spicy tuna I got was a frightening orange color (think pumpkin), the salmon had an odd firm texture to it that I don't ever recall having encountered before, and the seaweed salad consisted of pieces of seaweed that looked so identical that they appeared manufactured rather than grown.

I was very underwhelmed by this place and would go to Kiki on 9th Ave over this place any time.
author: Patrick B.

description:
I just ate here yesterday for lunch and it was alright.  The location of the place is pretty good because a lot of UCSF students/staff can eat here for pretty cheap.

The sushi was decent.  I ordered 6 cali rolls and nigiri which comes with a bowl of rice and soup.  It was a lunch combo for about 5.95 which is a alright deal.  The nigiri was nothing special and the cali roll was like any other cali roll.  The good part about this place is the prices since they're cheap.  2.75 for 6 cali rolls man!  and that price is the same for many other rolls.  

alright i give it 4 stars for the sushi and price!   

o yeah, sake is only 4 something and sapporo's are 2 something!!
author: Warren G.

description: It really cheap and the minimum for the credit card is only 5.00.  The rolls are cheap.  I tried the chicken teriyaki which is 6.95 and a dollar cheaper at lunch.  I would really want to come back and try the Philly cheese roll.  Why?  because its 3.65 a roll and has cream cheese, avocado which is good for the heart and lower cholesterol, and salmon in it.   I want to taste the combination of all three.  It would explode in my mouth.  The trolley bus number 6  take you here.
author: John F.

description: Delicious seaweed salad, excellent prices, excellent service!  Everything I've had here has been delicious, and I'm always surrounded by happy people eating whatever they're into.  I have a weakness for anything eel, and the Dragon Roll.  At the prices, it's worth a trip on the Muni just to check it out!
author: M P.

description: Good food. Just really slow.  It seems like there are just 2 people working most of the time and a restaurant full of customers.
author: Laura W.

description:
My friend and I were feeling nostalgic (nothing brings those feeling out quite like having a surgeon operate on the brain of one's parent).  Since we were already at the UCSF Parnassus hospital, we thought, why not relive our days of glory (from a time when we thought a California roll was real sushi and that Saba was raw).  Now a days, you will be hard pressed to find someone who is more of a sushi snob than I am (especially for not actually being Japanese).

You See Sushi (the artist formerly known as We Be Sushi) is a teeny tiny place, w/o a bar, and a handful of tables beneath some tiny and colorful IKEA-style lamps.  We got a sampling of rolls and nigiri.  In fact, we had 4 hand rolls (one of which was a custom made saba-gari roll, which is not on the menu - highly accommodating!), a 49er roll, an eel roll, and some albacore and tai nigiri.  I'll admit, the tai was totally disgusting.  And when I say "tai" I don't mean the Japanese snapper either - it's just your run of the mill Red Snapper.  But everything else was pretty decent - fresh even!  The rice was surprisingly pleasant as well (even though there was waaaay too much of it with our nigiri).

We sat there for a long, long time, sipped our beer, and got very very full.  We were the last people to leave the restaurant having no one to rush or harass us in the least.  And you know what the best part was?  Our total came to $33.  For that price, it's still the best sushi fix that you can get around.  Just don't order the tai!
author: Athos K.

description: Really good sushi for not a whole lot of money. The waitress was good about refilling our water and tea. We got the special, Salmon Tempura, which was amazing. I will definitely go there again.
author: Shawn B.

description: Yummy fresh sushi at reasonable prices. The spider roll and spicy tuna roll were great too.  Love this place!
author: Julie P.

description: Yes service is not too great and the tables are set so close together that people can hear every word you're saying and by the end of dinner everyone would have gotten to know each other. I, however, come to You See Sushi for their chicken terriyaki. It's a little bit crunchy just the way I like it! I've brought friends to try it and they loved it and they are now spreading the word about the chicken terriyaki.
author: Goldie L.

description: I came here tonight and picked up 2 rolls.  The dragon roll was great, the california roll was ok.  The prices are pretty cheap. The food was ready fast an the place was clean.
author: Wes P.

description: This place isn't fancy like many Japanese establishments, but it's cheap and gets the job done when the craving for raw fish hits.  Nigiri servings are generous, and the fish is decently fresh.  The lunch and dinner specials are recommended.  Do not get the non-sushi items.
author: Angband A.

description: My friends and I can't seem to get enough of this place. When we're starving and craving an immense amount of food, we'll come here. Parking is limited, yet that doesn't stop us from paying a decent price for more than decent food. I especially love the mugs they serve green tea in. Only been here for lunch, will try out dinner some time soon.
author: Cerina C.

description:
1 star:  cheap prices
2 stars:  friendly & quick service (the chef greets you upon arrival)
3 stars:  good fish
4 stars:  never have to wait for a table

Whenever my boyfriend and I are craving sushi but don't have the patience or expenses to deal with trendy/popular places, we head over to You See Sushi. 
Usually for under $30 total (including tip and a large hot sake) we kill our craving with a big plate topped with 3 pieces each of hamachi & maguro sashimi, a rock'n'roll, spicy tuna roll, saba nigiri, an appetizer of mixed Tempura, and two bowls of steaming miso soup.
Of course, you can be simple and go with one of the dinner specials for under $10 a person!

This isn't the place to go to if you're looking a trendy type place or for sushi that melts in your mouth. But it is the place to hit when you want good fresh fish for a great price with a small mellow group of friends or your honey.
author: Olivia B.

description: Its close to UCSF campus so we went here alll the time, but its just average.  Good lunch specials.  Chicken teriyaki is way too salty.
author: Maureen K.

description:
We like this place.  We frequented it a LOT on our way to or from visiting out newborn twins in the UCSF NICU.  Though the food is pretty standard fare, it is very nice quality and very reasonably priced.  Once we were done with UCSF, we often drove over the hill to pick-up the sushi.  

The owners are very friends and always ask us about the kids
author: Nick K.

description: My favorite place in San Francisco to get a bento box, the chicken teriyaki is off the hook!
author: Jill E.

description: You See Sushi is one of my happy places.  It's right in my neighborhood, easily walkable, and until recently (I graduated) it was a 5 minute walk from school.  The awesome ladies who work here know all of my friends and me because we come in so often.  I love the Hawaiian roll and the 49er roll.  Sashimi and nigiri are tasty too.  It's way affordable and better than any other comparably-priced sushi place I've been.  Unless I feel like going all out for Koo or Ebisu in my neighborhood, You See Sushi is my go-to.
author: Katie M.

description: Extremely inexpensive sushi that is fairly decent. Don't come here expecting top of the line Japanese food, but if you're looking for a friendly hole in the wall to enjoy a casual, good tasting meal that hardly dents the wallet this is it.
author: Tony S.

description: YES, service is not that great, but the food is! Sushi is fresh. I'm a fan, and I'll be back!!!
author: Linda P.

description: After getting my haircut from Jenny at 10th and Judah, who is awesome!  My husband and I went to have lunch at You see Sushi....Great place for Sushi and not that expensive....we love sushi and have been lookin for places like this....our favorite was the Grilled Salmon Teryaki roll for only $3.95....go check it out.....
author: Peanut D.

description: This is a good place to go when you want some okay sushi for a good price. I used to go here for lunch all of the time when I was staying in the Inner Sunset to grab a Sapporo, some edamame and a small roll. If you go there for lunch as opposed to dinner, the waitress is happier and will serve things faster.  The lunch special is a great deal and you get free tea.
author: Chelsea H.

description: This place is consistent.  They are now one of my go to spots because they've never let me down.  My favorites are the asparagus n' ell roll and the hawaiin roll.  The fact that they're closed on Sunday has gotten me a couple of times, but you can't hate too much on that.
author: Ray S.

description:
For cheap sushi, you can't go wrong here. I just discovered this place the other day and went with 6 friends for my birthday. It's my favorite new cheap sushi joint!

5 stars for the quantity and quality of food... now this isn't a 5 star restaurant, obviously. But for cheap sushi in SF, it's a great find. For 7 of us, with at least 5 beers, some sake, and so much food we almost couldn't finish, our total bill was only $100. And their quantity options are great- you can get sashimi in 3, 6, or 9 pieces (and the Toro Maguro sashimi- 3pcs for $3- was to die for!). 

The service is lacking, but I sort of expected that would be the case, so I'm not docking them any stars. You don't go to cheap sushi for the service. They weren't happy that we had so many people coming in at 9pm (they close at the ridiculously early time of 9:45 on weekends!), but we're all good restaurant people and know that sushi is quick, so we felt okay coming in 45 mins before closing. I think they hated us at first, and wouldn't serve us drinks until they sat us (which took about 15 minutes)... but our server got much nicer as the meal wore on, probably because we were nice, undemanding, and she realized it would be a decently large check.

I will definitely be back, although will try to go a little earlier and with fewer people.
author: Brandi C.

description: We have been getting take-out sushi from here for several years.  The food is consistently good and well priced (especially for sushi.)  The service is prompt and efficient.  Last night when I went in to pick up my order, I commented on the cute little paper dolls hung around the restaurant.  I asked if they were for sale, as I knew my daughter would like one, but was told that they were not.  As I went to pay, the woman at the counter took down one of the dolls and gave it to me.  How sweet is that?!  Our favorites include the soft-shelled crab maki and  the salmon and avocado maki -- really fresh and yummy!
author: Gina F.

description: Another favorite spot. Great sushi, inexpensive prices and wonderful staff! Even though I'm in the Mission, I still make the drive to the Inner Sunset.
author: Amy C.

description: Tell me where on earth you can get, green tea, miso soup, a california roll, nigiri, salmon and unagi all for under $8!  Tell me, WHERE?!?!? I just had lunch here with a friend and it's a spot that I've passed tons of times on my way to the inner Sunset, and I have to say that I was sleeping on You See Sushi!  Who knew?  Thanks Chelsea for the review!  (You see, I should have known you're the Sushi Guru baby!)
author: Mijiza M. S.

description:
if u happen to be in the parnassus area and need a quick sushi fix without too much drain on your wallet, this is the place. friendly, fast service, with decent food....
safe choice for lunch.  
on downside, the place can get a bit cramped, so not great for more the 2-4 people.
author: Roy N.

description: Came and dinned here with 3 others and we all agreed that 'you see what you get'.  We ordered and shared a variety of rolls for a very good price.  Definitely try the Lady in Red- spicy tuna & avocado wrapped with tuna.  I was a big fan of the sparkling sake.
author: Lisa C.

description: This is the perfect neighborhood sushi place. I eat here almost every week. It's cheap, fast, and always tasty. Plus they have cute mugs for tea with pics of sushi on them. The rolls aren't fancy, and they are on the small side (so order a few more than usual) but they are always fresh and super good.
author: Melissa A.

description: I'm not a sushi snob of any sort, but I enjoy the experience.  I am writing this review because I just ate a ton of sushi and two Sapporo for a little over 20 bucks!  I left very satisfied and I will be back....a lot.
author: Malik J.

description:
Nothing flashy about the place, but it's decent quality, plus it's like that cute old little neighborhood place that you just can't say anything bad about because you've grown to love it and without it nearest decent place would be much farther and far more expensive.
It's also my wife's most favorite sushi place in SF.
author: Alex S.

description: Had lunch with my best friend here today (oh, this perfect sunny, albeit windy, day). I had the lunch special with a spicy tuna and avocado roll, and various nigiri. It was all good, and a good deal too. $5.95 for the special. Both of your lunch specials together with tip was only $15! It gets busy around lunchtime so there was a short wait, but otherwise it was good. Would have preferred the fish on my nigiri a little colder, but it was still good.
author: Anita C.

description: been giving lots of 3-stars lately. but it seems appropriate for the places i've been to recently. you see has got some good lunch and dinner specials. amount of food and pricing is pretty good. i live in the neighborhood and have been exploring all the different cuisines around my house and have been here a few times in the past few weeks. definitely an economical way to have a little japanese food.
author: Georgia W.

description:
I am a fan because the price is right for the quality of sushi that you get. Obviously if the money is not an issue, I would go eat at sushi Koo on Irving every day and every meal. But if your budget is tight, you see sushi becomes really appealing especially for such a sushi lover like me. 

To be honest with you, I was a skeptic at first before I even tried out this place. How could good quality sushi be so cheap? But as it turned out, it can.  I LOVE their spicy tuna roll... and have tried a few things on the menu, some of which I like some I don't. If you love spicy stuff like me, I would recommend the dinner #2 and you can ask for a substitution of cucumber roll and Inari if you don't like those things. They charge like 50 cents extra or something cheap if you replace Inari with salmon for example. You can't go wrong with the spicy tuna and their albacore is surprisingly fresh. 

I also love how they serve miso soup with cabbage and fresh carrots while you are waiting for your food. I would go there again and again if I live nearby UCSF. For the price they charge, the quality of their sushi is quite top-notched, and for that reason I give this place a 4 stars.
author: Mary P.

description: Was nearby and son hungry so we stopped in for an early dinner. Were very few people in there but since it was only 5:30pm I didn't think anything about it. Ordered bowl of rice for son. They do not seem to use sushi rice, just regular rice pretty undercooked. The eel in my rock and roll and in the nigiri pieces was off tasting. Miso soup a little watery not horrible but not amazing. I didn't get sick so I gave it 2 not one stars. But I will not go back here.
author: Precita M.

description: My husband & I call this little gem, Cheap-bisu (given that it's only a few blocks from the amazingly good yet pricey Ebisu).  Yummy fresh sushi (not the most inventive menu - but all the traditional favorites), friendly staff, minimal wait, and you'll think they made a mistake on the bill it's so low.  The only drawback - if you like low salt soy sauce, bring your own or be prepared to water it down.
author: Kristin S.

description: Definitely not authentic sushi. It will get by if you hunger for some japanese sushi. I had the bento box with chicken, tempura, and california roll. We also ordered a few rolls spider, spicy tuna. 2 stars is pushing it but if you've eaten sushi and been around you'll know what I mean. Quick eat you get in and out. Small place good.
author: Larry L.

description: Used to be called 'we be sushi'... now 'you see sushi' - probably because it is down the street from the UC Med Ctr...clever!  Great place for some good inexpensive sushi.  The lunch specials are the best.  For under 7 bucks, you get miso soup, rice, 6 pieces of spicy tuna roll...and 5  nigiri's.  I usually ask them to not put the 'sauce' on top of my rice.  Turn around is quick..great place.
author: Lise T.

description:
My mom works at UCSF and when I have lunch with her this is the place we always go. It's within walking distance from her work. Their sushi here is cheap but pretty delicious and taste its worth. They give you complimentary tea and miso soup. I say it ain't miso soup if there is no tofu/seaweed. There's has both. Yee. My usual is the chicken teriyaki lunch special. That's what's up and where it should be. I would argue there chicken teriyaki is the best in the city. I will. They grill the chicken and they do this thing with the sauce like they caramalize the teriyaki on top so that when you bite it, it is crunchy. That alone gives it a special flavor and legendary hit. Not to mention their salad is great. Tempura is fried perfectly along with seasoning. 

The waiters are very nice. They remember our faces and pretty much can guess what our order is. 

The place is small and fits about 30, so it's a mad rush since you need to beat the UCSF employees. Wait for food is normal time like 10-15 minutes. Parking is a hassle since it's right near a hospital. Could use UCSF's parking lot and walk. Or just take public transportation since it stops right there. 

Price is cheap and totally worth it. If you don't buy chicken teriyaki when you're there, you will just waste your time. Must have.
author: Philbert K.

description: Very mediocre sushi.  The prices were very reasonable, and the miso was delicious, but other than that, I couldn't find much reason to go.  It was a pleasant enough experience, but, eh....
author: Jackie D.

description: Came here for the first time. It is dirt cheap and is a good option when you are feeling so lazy you do not even want to put thought into deciding which sushi to order. Their dinner specials, comprised of several different items are the perfect portion size and offer a decent variety.
author: Alicia J.

description: I've been coming to this place for years! The sushi is good and cheap! And no worries because the fish is fresh!! I ALWAYS get the meals bc of the great deals. My favorite meal = shrimp tempura roll, rock and roll roll, four pieces of nigiri and a bowl of miso soup = $10. How could you go wrong?? Plus you get these lovely sticks of carrots to start of the meal. =)
author: Angela T.

description: Came back for lunch and tried sushi this time. I got the lunch special D- spicy tuna avocado roll, 4 pieces of nigiri, miso soup and rice. Delicious and only 6 dollars! Only complaint is one of the nigiri pieces (albacore) tasted a little fishy i.e. not the freshest it could be. My lunch companion had teriyaki chicken, which I don't usually want and never order. But for some reason it was pretty appealing. But it might just be that my hunger right now is altering my perception of food as I try to judge them from memory.
author: Xiaoyin W.

description: Good priced sushi for an okay type of taste. Not the best type of sushi, but not the worst.
author: Janel Y.

description: Prices are good...the sushi is Ok...Although it does get busy on certain nights in here... I see more people hitting the soup place next door or the indian resturaunt next door...i think You See is open a little later and  no wait usually..
author: New Dilly G.

description: cheap yet gross, you can get better sushi at safeway or whole foods which is nearby and cheaper
author: Aaron D.

description: My favorite neighborhood sushi joint for my everyday sushi needs. Inexpensive, consistently good sushi served by the same faces each time I go in. No attitude, no scene and a table is always availalbe. Why go to Ebisu when you can go to You See? I always get the rock-n-roll!
author: Pam D.

description:
run of the mill, but decently priced.  it's... just average.  through and through.

not sure if i'd come here if my buddies didn't live like a block away.  don't go out of your way... the city has so many more options if you're looking for mediocre.
author: Steven C.

description: This place is the one of the things I miss most about living in the inner sunset. Their spicy tuna rolls are a staple and we always end up ordering 2-3 orders because it's just so damn good. I'm getting hungry just thinking about it. Really friendly staff, minimal wait. I make the trek from the mission sometimes to get my You See Sushi fix.
author: Evelyn G.

description: Great great great place. Cheap, excellent quality sushi. Zero trendy atmosphere, but who needs it? Hokki-Gai Nigiri for $2.50? I'll be back!  I want to go there right now!
author: Bowen D.

description: You get what you pay for. Very inexpensive, so portions size reflects the price. Not a fancy place, seems more like they cater to UCSF students and employees on their breaks. Their miso soup doesn't have tofu or nori. They use cabbage instead. I'd rather pay higher prices along 9th ave. It makes the 16th potereo safeway sushi a 10.
author: Robin L.

description: The reason I would recommend it is becuse it is a great hole-in-the wall kind of place that I go to often for take-out. It's a good sushi-on-a-budget with good service. I live nearby so I'm a little biased but when you look at the quality to price ratio, I'd rather go here than anywhere else.
author: June C.

description:
service is excellent.
price is spectacular. the dinner special consists of two rolls & six pieces of sushi for 9.99.....i mean what a steal?!

i do have to agree with my bf though...i mean you can afford it but you are not satisfied...because we both have had better you know.

it is though a great great sushi fix if you are down & out like me.
author: Tiger Lily ..

description:
i had hoped this place would be ok-mediocre, because it's right near my house. i ordered things that should be nearly impossible to screw up: edamame, miso soup, plain rice. the rice was fine. the edamame was way too salty and looked pretty beat-up. what was really sad, though, was the miso soup: it was not miso soup, but watery flavorless broth with what appeared to be cabbage and no pieces of tofu at all! cheap miso soup mixes are thousands of times better than this crap.

the restaurant is also completely filthy with an open kitchen so you can see just how many health codes are being violated. it is disgusting and it boggles my mind that people would order sushi here - it seems like a suicide mission. 

i guess take-out is the big business, because there are never more than 4 people eating in the restaurant and i'm not sure how else it would stay in business for so long. it needs to shut down so that a halfway decent restaurant can move in.
author: Cara F.

description: i havent actually tried their sushi rolls or sashimi, but i came here once to get a chicken teriyaki dinner meal for take-out. the price was really reasonable and it came with two california rolls and a small side salad. the main dish wasn't anything exciting. i find it pretty hard for chicken teriyaki to NOT be satisfying, so i was surprised when i felt pretty disappointed with my meal. the rice had a strange texture to it, and i had about 2-3 pieces of chicken that i spit out because they were chewy/fatty.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
The soup seemed to be made of MSG with napa cabbage and carrots, instead of miso with tofu and wakame. 

The maki rolls were small, but good. 

The nigiri was not fresh (tasted a little fishy) and also on the small side.

The sake was not very drinkable. 

I work nearby so I've been here a few times. This place wasn't awful, but it wasn't very good either. I'll probably be back, anyway.

I think this place is at the same level as KiKi at 9th and Irving, except for one difference: Quality is not very consistent here, sometimes the rolls and nigiri are better than my latest trip today, whereas KiKi is constantly mediocre.
author: a a.

description: Food here is decent, but the table was sticky and I felt a bit ignored.  I ordered udon and got broth and noodles, nothing exciting.  The price was right though.
author: Matt S.

description: After having eaten countless meals at Hotei and Ebisu we decided to try this little place.  While I have always thought "hole in the wall" sushi was something I would never try,  I have to say I was pretty impressed.  The menu was simple and pretty generic as far as sushi goes,  but what earns it the 4 stars is that its inexpensive and has no wait.  The bill was less than $24 for 3 people and we had our pick of tables.  4 stars for in and out and cheap! I cant believe it took me 3 years to try this place.
author: Blair F.

description: Although not the art and flavor of Koo, this is the most casual, comfortable, affordable sushi joint in the city.  Consistently decent food that's cheaper than just about any other restuarant in the Inner Sunset - and wait staff that learn all your quirks if you become regular customers.  Highly recommended.  Where else can you listen to the Bee Gees while dining on kampyo-maki?
author: t k.

description: A favorite! Consistantly good sushi, and you can get gut-busting full for such a small amount of money. My man and I eat like freakin royalty here. And the waitress knows to keep the sake coming, she's great. Sometimes it gets busy within moments and there is a little bit of a wait, but it's worth it.
author: M B.

description:
the cheapest sushi in town! nothin fancy, but they have $2.00 rolls, and i looooves me some sushi so i'll take it!  i did get sick one time...but i'm trying not to hold that against them. i've been there TONS, and it's only happened once.

best for take-out...no atmostphere in the place, staff not extremely friendly, but they do their thing, so i say just pick up your cheap sushi and bounce!
author: Hella M.

description: EXCELLENT sushi, excellent teriyaki!  Try it, you'll love it, especially for the price.  The food is 5 stars, the ambiance brings it a bit more down to earth since it's a tiny bit uncomfortable when it gets crowded.
author: Roxanne M.

description: With a name like You See Sushi, I had my healthy share of doubts for this random Japanese restaurant on Judah Street. Sure, it's probably not a restaurant I would take my friend for a birthday dinner. BUT, for $7 to $12 you can get a delicous and well prepared Japanese entrees. I got the Tempura Udon and I was pleasantly surprised at the flaky batter of the tempura. And the tempura plate was much largerthan I expected! It didn't sit in my stomach like a fried golf ball. The udon broth was tasty and noodles were good, too. I also ordered two sushi rolls from the menu because it was cheap and because I didn't think the udon was going to keep me full enough. I ended up sharing the sushi rolls and left feeling quite content and not ripped off. Everyone in my dinner party agreed the restaurant was an excellent choice for the food and value. About 2 blocks from UCSF, this place is a great find for the price. (We were visiting a family member at the hospital and after 4 hours, ready to eat.) If I'm in the area, I'll definitely go back. By the way, I liked that they started with a mug of sliced carrots (healthier option than bread)!
author: Julianne C.

description: corner hideaway for the ucsf contingent and downhillers.  been there forever and the service smacks of it, not to be coddled unless you are a regular, which i am not ... but at least i didnt get totilla'd height"d (blind sided rudeness and attitude) - oh the food, the fancier the roll the tastier the selection ... but hey, i got a decent sushi at a decent price with decent service ... satisfied customer
author: tim y.

description:
i have an addiction problem...i've tried to get help but i dont have the willpower. yes, i am addicted to sushi!!! and i mean good quality sushi but for good quality, my wallet tends to become smaller and thinner as time passes. so, when i need a fix i go to You See Sushi. it's a small hole in the wall place but hey, they keep their bathroom pretty clean & useable..so, it ain't that bad after all.

i usually judge my sushi rating based on the following freshness w/these orders: an order of ikura nigiri, saba nigiri, hamachi (nigiri or sashimi preferably), and uni nigiri. if all or most of "my usual order" passes the "freshness" test...then the restaurant gets a good rating.

let's just say that i go there at least once a week for my sushi fix b/c it's cheap and pretty fresh. they charge an order of uni nigiri (thats sea urchin sushi for those who dont know) for $3.00 & that's 2 pieces. the average at other places are $5.50 for 2 pcs.!! so $1.50/pc. of uni?? i am sooo not complaining and it's pretty fresh!! the hamachi sashimi is awesome...nice piece of hamachi belly w/it's buttery goodness..6pcs. for $6!! if u want more, they have 9pcs. for $9--basically a buck a piece...shoot, i ain't complaining about that either!! the ikura however was a little skimped on last time i went. i expected a heaping teaspoon full on top of the sushi rice but it wasn't. that's ok though, i'll look over that since i love this place.

they have this special on the chalkboard called the "You see special" and it's good. 6 pcs. of prawn tempura roll, 5 pcs. of eel & cucumber (or eel & avocado--i forgot), and 4 pcs. nigiri (hamachi, red snapper, salmon, and tuna)..all that for $9.95. that's 15 pcs. of sushi for $10?? it's yummy! and i love how the hot rice rolled w/the hot prawn tempura just sorta melts in ur mouth so u know it's made fresh. 

you see sushi?? definitely a place to go for cheap fresh sushi.
author: Yolanda L.

description: Not fancy, nor top quality, nor super authentic. But this is good sushi for the price. Tried the 5.95 sushi combo lunch special. Got a bowl of rice, miso soup with cabbage?, spicy tuna sushi, salmon, nigiri, etc sushi.  Decent sushi, tasted fine. Great for the price. I would come back, no problem if I was around the area.
author: Dijon Y.

description: love it.  great sushi, amazing sushi for the price.  pretty sure the tuna was melting in our mouths.  we went in and were the only ones in there.  the environment isn't terribly stimulating, but we were hungry for sushi not stimulation and we fed ourselves in excess for rather cheap.  lady in red is fantastic.  give it a shot, you'll be glad.
author: Ryan H.

description: Nothing special stands out about this place.  I really wanted it to be better given that it's within walking distance for me.  Yes the food is definitely inexpensive, but the rolls aren't too exciting, the fish is not the freshest, the tempura is ok and the ambiance is fine.  Just average.  Very average.  Tried several of the rolls and a tempura/teriyaki bento box for lunch.  Did the trick, but not much more than that...
author: Sanjiv B.

description: you don't know what good sushi is until you've had bad sushi. don't worry. they serve good sushi here. if you're budget conscious, i would stick to the lunch combo ($6 something) or their dinner combo ($10 or so). in both, you get a decent variety of sushi at a fraction of what it would cost elsewhere. i like to pay a little extra and mix and match my dinner combo so i can get lots of nigiri with spicy tuna rolls instead of the cheaper california or mushroom roll.
author: Tin-Tin E.

description: average price for average sushi (though much much better than Kiki).  I felt I was being ignored by the waitress (I was literally the only person of color in the restaurant the time I went).  I waited for 20 minutes to get my order taken, which was taken by one of the cooks/chefs in the back... he, too, noticed that I was not attended to for quite some time.
author: Grace M.

description: I've been to many sushi places in SF and this is probably the cheapest and best value.  You may not have the best cut of fish but you never leave hungry and I don't get sick.  The lady is very friendly and she actually recognizes you.
author: A N.

description: I live right across the street from this place and grab a roll whenever I can. The quality has gotten mixed reviews, but I actually think the quality is rather good and the sushi chef does a great job. I prefer their rolls to Kiki's by a longshot. The owner/chef at You See Sushi is a bonified Japanese man, which helps with the authenticity. All you budget-conscious Kiki fans, I highly recommend you make a trip over to You see. i think you will be pleasantly surprised, and converted, like me.
author: Iris M.

description: this place has sustained me many times during my UC days.  not too thrilled about their sashimis but their nigiris and specialty rolls are quite tasty. teriyaki dishes are a good option for the non-sushi eating populace.
author: aj s.

description:
i've been going her for yrs for lunch just cause its close to school (ucsf).  its cheap and okay for what you pay for, the waitress are nice and friendly.  price is good  ...you get what u pay for.  

but man i went there today with my friend.  i got D and my friend got C.  my spicy tuna roll was filled with avacado mostly, that I couldn't even taste the tuna in the roll.  even my friend's CA roll had mostly avacados in her roll too.  i dunno...maybe they r trying to cut cost or something due to the bad economy.  But their always busy, so i doubt it really affecting them.
author: chris l.

description: Decent sushi and well-priced at a convenient location. But I once got refused water because I wasn't ordering my own meal...
author: Sam H.

description: I've honestly had better sushi from the grocery store (Whole Foods, etc.).   Everything at You See is just average...
author: A S.

description: My partner and I love this place.  We've been going at least 2x/month for years, and it's consistently great-tasting, with a friendly & personable owner and staff.  It doesn't try to compete with high-end sushi places and has no fancy airs.  Rather, it's very much a cozy-feeling neighborhood-ish, reasonably priced, locals-pleasing kind of place.  Tourists won't find it unless you bring them there for a funky sushi experience.   I recommend the soft-shell crab roll, or ask what they'd suggest if you want to get creative.
author: Cindy R.

description: ok food, great spot and super cheap!
author: kathleen A.
